title: APIs
body: APIs

title: Overview
body: FA’s APIs provide you with programmatic access to the data you have stored in FA, allowing you to build your own solutions on top of your portfolio management system. FA’s APIs allow you to extensively manage the communication between FA and the other applications you develop and maintain.

title: Functionality
body: Integrate FA with your own platforms and services through APIs

title: Functionality
body: Search, add, and modify your data via API calls - access data in FA through standard APIs. The fundamental data types (contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, and trade orders) provide you with different options to search and modify data.

title: Functionality
body: Generate and fetch reports – get reports for specific contacts, portfolios, transactions, or trade orders in JSReport.

title: Functionality
body: Browse and try out FA APIs – browse documentation for the available GraphQL endpoints and define queries using interactive developer tools: see API integrations in FA Developer guide.

title: Functionality
body: Manage data access

title: Functionality
body: Restrict data access - define whether or not a given user has access to a given portfolio's or contact's information.

title: Supported formats
body: FA offers APIs based on two technologies – GraphQL and REST. We recommend using GraphQL APIs – they are constantly updated and provide access to all necessary data and functionality. Our REST APIs are in maintenance mode and are not actively developed.

title: GraphQL APIs
body: GraphQL APIs provide access to the following data:

title: REST APIs
body: Basic APIs

title: Related links
body: API integrations in FA Developer guide

title: Related links
body: API integrations in FA Developer

title: Market Data Connector
body: Market Data Connector

title: Overview
body: Market Data Connector connects your FA with global market data providers to receive end-of-day (EOD) prices and instrument reference data, thus keeping your position valuations and instrument data up-to-date. You can connect to multiple market data providers simultaneously and flexibly fetch the data you need.

title: Functionality
body: Fetch instrument market prices

title: Functionality
body: Connect your instruments to market data connectors - you can connect to up to three market data providers simultaneously, and select which securities' prices to fetch from which connector. For example, you can fetch prices from separate connectors to your bonds and all other instruments. To do this, you can define a connector-specific update code for your security, or automatically fetch corresponding update codes to all securities the system can find through the connector.

title: Functionality
body: Fetch the history of end-of-day prices to an instrument - you can fetch the history of the EOD close prices for a security through a market data connector of your choice. You can configure the earliest date for which prices are fetched, to ensure you don't get prices for longer history than you need.

title: Functionality
body: Automatically fetch newest EOD prices at night - you can schedule nightly updates to fetch EOD close prices for all your securities. You can configure for how many days' prices you want to update each night.

title: Functionality
body: Update prices for all securities for x number of days - you can update prices for all securities for a selected time period - you can fetch prices for all securities for 7, 30, 365 days or since the configured earliest market data date.

title: Functionality
body: Look for missing or delayed prices during the day - all EOD prices might not be available at the same time when they are automatically fetched at night. This module provides you with a tool to search for and update missing or delayed prices multiple times during the day, to ensure you receive the latest available prices when they become available through the connector.

title: Functionality
body: Fetch the intraday prices - you can fetch the intraday prices for selected securities if these prices are provided by the market data connector.

title: Functionality
body: Use intraday prices in rebalancing - some market data connectors offer intraday prices. If your connector supports intraday prices you can use them to rebalance your portfolios with Model Portfolio Management.

title: Functionality
body: Fetch instrument reference data

title: Functionality
body: Connect your securities to security data connectors - you can connect your securities to security reference data provider. The exact instrument information available varies from provider to provider, and may vary depending on your contract with the security data provider.

title: Functionality
body: Create new securities with reference data - you can search for securities by ISIN code or other available identifiers through the security data connector, and add them as new securities in FA.

title: Functionality
body: Update your existing instruments with reference data - you can update your existing security data with information provided by your security data provider. You can select which information you want to update, initiate the update manually or automatically update your security data on a scheduled basis.

title: Supported service providers
body: To use the Market Data Connector module, you need to have access to one or more of the supported market data connectors listed below.

title: Trading Connector
body: Trading Connector

title: Overview
body: FA’s Trading Connector automates your trade order management by sending orders to your preferred trading venue. You can thus monitor the status and execution information of your trade orders in real time.

title: Functionality
body: Send trade orders from FA to a trading platform of your choice

title: Functionality
body: Send trade orders via a trading integration - select trade orders in FA and send them forward to your trading platform. When sending orders via a trading integration, your orders are executed outside of FA. You can use one of the supported trading connectors, as long as the connector supports sending trade orders. You can also automate sending trade orders based on a schedule and custom criteria. For example, you can automatically send all buy and sell orders with status "Accepted" forward every day at 16:00.

title: Functionality
body: Connect to multiple trading platforms simultaneously - you can connect to multiple trading platforms at the same time, and you can route your trade orders to suitable trading connectors. For example, you can route your fund orders to Euroclear FundsPlace, while your stock and ETF orders are routed to Infront. You can also automate the trade order routing to the correct trading platform - automatic order routing requires additional configuration.

title: Functionality
body: Automatically receive execution information about your orders from a trading platform

title: Functionality
body: Receive order status updates and execution information on sent orders - trading connectors support automatically updating the trade order status and execution/payment information to trade orders you have sent forward with one of our trading connectors. The exact frequency and content of these updates vary from connector to connector.

title: Functionality
body: Receive drop copy session messages - Receive near real-time information about trades executed in other trading platforms. The incoming feed of orders updates or creates new trade orders in FA. Drop copy sessions are supported in FIX formats only for certain connections (see the Supported formats and service providers table).

title: Functionality
body: Send execution information on orders received in FA

title: Functionality
body: Send order updates on the trade orders received by your fund - select trade orders executed in FA and send trade order update messages and execution information from FA to your fund distributor. You can use one of the supported trading connectors, as long as the connector supports receiving trade orders. You can also automate sending trade order updates based on a schedule and custom criteria.

title: Supported formats and service providers
body: To use the Trading Connector, you need to have access to one or more of the supported trading connectors listed below. Some counterparties require onboarding with a separate cost.

title: Logging in
body: The FA platform is available at <your_instance>.fasolutions.com. To log in, you need to have a user account (created by an administrator who manages the FA platform in your company). Depending on the settings, you can log in to FA with the following:

title: Logging in
body: Username and password. If you need to change your password, follow the instructions in Change your password.

title: Logging in
body: Two-factor authentication that is more secure and requires entering a one-time verification code from the authenticator app in addition to your username and password. To learn how to enable two-factor authentication, see Enable two-factor authentication.

title: Logging in
body: When logging in to FA for the first time, you need to set up your login information. To do this, follow the instructions in the sections below.

title: First time login with username and password
body: When logging in to FA for the first time, do the following:

title: First time login with username and password
body: Click the Forgot password? link on the login page, enter your username, and click Submit.

title: First time login with username and password
body: Open the email you received from FA and click the link to reset credentials. The “Reset password” email is sent from no-reply@email.fasolutions.com and is valid for 5 minutes.

title: First time login with username and password
body: Set your password by entering it twice on the Update password page that opens. The password can't be your username or any of your previous 3 passwords, and it must contain:

title: First time login with username and password
body: At least 8 characters.

title: First time login with username and password
body: One small letter.

title: First time login with username and password
body: One capital letter.

title: First time login with username and password
body: One number.

title: First time login with username and password
body: Re-enter your username and password on the login page that opens.

title: First time login with username and password
body: You are logged in to FA.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: When logging in to FA for the first time with two-factor authentication, do the following:

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Make sure you have an authenticator app installed on your mobile device.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Click the Forgot password? link on the login page, enter your username, and click Submit.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Open the email you received from FA and click the link to reset your credentials. The “Reset password” email is sent from no-reply@email.fasolutions.com and is valid for 5 minutes. The Mobile Authenticator Setup page opens.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Scan the QR code on the setup page with your authenticator app. Scanning the code provides your authenticator app with information required to generate verification codes for your next logins.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Enter the one-time code from your authenticator app. You can also name your device. Click Submit.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Set your password by entering it twice on the Update password page that opens. The password can't be your username or any of your previous 3 passwords, and it must contain:

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: At least 8 characters.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: One small letter.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: One capital letter.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: One number.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: Re-enter your username and password on the login page that opens.

title: First time login with two-factor authentication
body: You are logged in to FA.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: FA allows you to enable two-factor authentication for your user account. When two-factor authentication is enabled, you need to provide a one-time verification code from an authenticator app on your mobile device in addition to your username and password. If you need to reset two-factor authentication for a new device, for example, enable it again.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: To enable two-factor authentication, do the following:

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: Make sure you have an authentication app installed on your mobile device.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: In FA Back, click the Manage two-factor authentication icon on the left and reauthenticate yourself with your username and password. The Mobile Authenticator Setup page opens.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: Scan the QR code with the authenticator app on your mobile device. Scanning the code provides your app with the information required to generate verification codes for your next logins.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: Enter the one-time code from your authenticator app. You can also name your device.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: Click Submit.

title: Enable two-factor authentication
body: Next time you log in to FA, you need to enter a one-time verification code from your authenticator app in addition to your username and password. To learn more about logging in, see Logging in.

title: Change your password
body: If you need to change your password, you can reset it via the FA login page. To set a new password, click the Forgot password? link on the login page and follow the instructions for logging in for the first time in Logging in.

title: Access for customers
body: Two apps are available for your customers to view and manage their investments: FA Client Portal and FA Front. We recommend that you use FA Client Portal app. FA Front is an older application that we don't develop anymore.

title: Portfolio management
body: Portfolio management is the core of FA system. Here is what you can do:

title: Portfolio management
body: Store up-to-date information securities and market prices. FA system lets you handle a wide range of securities, such as equities, funds, bonds, options, future contracts, and any security types you need. To keep securities and market prices up-to-date, you can use one of FA's standard integrations.

title: Portfolio management
body: Manage client contacts. You can onboard your new clients, check and update the client information using FA's standard integrations.

title: Portfolio management
body: View portfolio positions. FA system provides detailed information for each portfolio position, including market values, purchase prices, exposure, accrued interest, and so on. Portfolio positions are calculated based on transactions, using the valuation method you chose for a portfolio.

title: Portfolio management
body: Keep track of account balances and provide credit to your clients. Similar to portfolio positions, account balance is calculated based on transactions. You can also keep track of the interest accrued on your accounts.

title: Portfolio management
body: Align portfolio holdings with investment objectives. FA system provides various tools for forming a portfolio and keeping it in line with your investment objectives. You can set up a strategy, model portfolio or investment plan and use them to rebalance your portfolios.

title: Portfolio management
body: Create trade orders and record transactions. Trade orders created in FA system are sent to external systems for execution. When the trade is completed, FA system creates transactions and updates portfolio positions.

title: Portfolio management
body: Run corporate actions to multiple customer portfolios at once.

title: Position calculation
body: FA system calculates portfolio positions based on transactions. When you save a transaction, position data is updated and report data recalculation is triggered. For more information about portfolio report recalculation, see Report data calculation in FA Admin guide.

title: Portfolio management - Quickstart
body: This section provides a step-by-step tutorial for forming a portfolio in FA Back. Follow it if you are new to the FA system and want to start using portfolio management.

title: Create securities
body: Create securities in the system and specify market prices. Follow the steps:

title: Create securities
body: Click New → New security and fill in the required fields:

title: Create securities
body: Switch to the Market data info tab to add the market price. Click Add market data and enter the current date and price.

title: Create securities
body: Click Save and close.

title: Create securities
body: You can find the created security in the Securities view.

title: Create a contact
body: Create a contact for the customer who is going to be the portfolio owner.

title: Create a contact
body: Click New → New contact and fill in the required fields:

title: Create a contact
body: Click Save & close.

title: Create a contact
body: You can find the created contact in the Contacts view.

title: Create a portfolio
body: Create a portfolio and add a cash account:

title: Create a portfolio
body: Open the Contacts view, select the contact you created and click New → New portfolio.

title: Create a portfolio
body: Fill in the required fields:

title: Create a portfolio
body: Switch to the Accounts tab to add a cash account. Click Add account and enter account number, currency, and name:

title: Create a portfolio
body: You can find the created portfolio in the Portfolios view or open it in the Overview to work with the portfolio investments.

title: Add portfolio cash
body: Add cash on the portfolio account:

title: Add portfolio cash
body: Click New → New transaction → Cash and fill in the transaction type (deposit), date, and amount. For the purpose of this quickstart, specify the same date for payment date and transaction date.

title: Add portfolio cash
body: Click Save & close.

title: Add portfolio cash
body: After you added cash on the portfolio account, you can see it in the Overview:

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Add a portfolio position based on the security you created:

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Click New → New transaction → Equity and fill in the fields:

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Security. Find the security you created (for example, by typing in the security code).

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Transaction type. Choose "Buy".

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Acc. FX rate. EUR to USD FX rate to use.

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Transaction date, Settlement date. For the purpose of this quickstart, enter the current date.

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Amount. The number of shares to buy.

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Unit price. To fetch the unit price you specified for the security, type "?" and press Enter.

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: The system calculates the transaction total amount based on the unit price, amount, and the FX rate you entered.

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: Click Save & close.

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: You can see in the Overview that the position is now part of the portfolio, and the cash amount on the portfolio account is reduced:

title: Add portfolio holdings
body: You can repeat the steps to add more securities and positions to fill in the portfolio.

title: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios
body: To run corporate actions, you can choose a workflow that suits you:

title: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios
body: To create corporate actions for specific securities and run them per portfolio, contact, or portfolio group, follow the steps described here.

title: Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios
body: To create, schedule, and run coupon payments and bond expirations for all securities in the system, see Mass-generate coupons and expirations.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Create and define a corporate action per security, specifying the corporate action type and details, such as date, transaction type, prices per share, ratios, and so on:

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Create a corporate action. You can choose from the following options:

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: To create a corporate action that affects a single customer or portfolio, click Menu and New - New corporate action. The customer or portfolio you have selected in the Overview is suggested as the default target.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: To create a corporate action that affects multiple portfolios, click New corporate action in the Corporate action view.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Choose the corporate action type (see Corporate action types).

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Fill in the fields in the upper part of the Corporate action run window for the selected corporate action type. For field descriptions for each corporate action type, see Corporate action types. Close the window or proceed to the next step.

title: Step 1 - Create and define a corporate action
body: Creating a corporate action does not yet affect any portfolios, because the corporate action has to be run to the selected portfolios first.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Create a corporate action run per portfolio or portfolio group, specifying tax information, and exchange rates. You can run the corporate action now or schedule it for a future date.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: To run or schedule the corporate action, do the following:

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: In the Corporate action view, click New corporate action. To run a previously defined corporate action, search for it in the Corporate action view and click New run.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Select the portfolios to include in the corporate action run and fill in the taxation information and exchange rates. Fill in the taxation information and exchange rates. For descriptions of the taxation and exchange rate fields, see Corporate action window in FA Back reference.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Choose if you want to schedule the corporate action for later or run it now:

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: To schedule the corporate action for later, specify the date and time, and click Schedule & close. For a scheduled corporate action, the process is complete.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: To run the corporate action now, click Run & close and proceed to the next step.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Review the transactions suggested by the system in the Transactions window. You can uncheck each transaction to prevent it from being created. If needed, click Change parameters to return to the previous window and edit the run settings.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: Click Accept and run to create the selected transactions.

title: Step 2 - Run a corporate action
body: The system then creates transactions in the selected portfolios using the corporate action security position on the morning of the corporate action (position after the previous day) and the information you defined.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: You can delete the run and the transactions created by it by doing the following:

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: In the Corporate action view, click on the corporate action and double-click the run. You can review the transactions created by the run by clicking Show transactions.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: Click Delete. The transactions created to the portfolios by the run are deleted.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: If you want to delete the corporate action itself or, for example, you imported a corporate action by mistake, do the following:

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: Delete all runs for the corporate action.

title: Delete runs and corporate actions
body: Double-click the corporate action and click Delete.

title: Related links
body: Corporate action window in FA Back reference

title: Handle rights issues
body: Rights issue consists of the following phases:

title: Handle rights issues
body: Registration of Subscription Rights

title: Handle rights issues
body: Exercise Subscription Rights by subscribing for shares (either company shares directly or Interim Shares)

title: Handle rights issues
body: If Interim Shares are used, exchange the interim shares for company shares

title: Handle rights issues
body: This document details the different ways the rights issues can be handled in FA platform using corporate action functionalities.

title: Handle rights issues
body: The rights issues can be handled differently depending on taxation. The key difference is whether the subscription rights are considered having some purchase value. For example, in some jurisdictions private person taxation requires subscription rights not having purchase price while company taxation requires the purchase price.

title: Handle rights issues
body: The example case used here is Enedo Plc's Rights Issue in 2021. In that rights issue the key details were the following:

title: Handle rights issues
body: Shareholders will receive three subscription rights for every one share owned (1:3 ratio). The ex-rights date is 12 March.

title: Handle rights issues
body: Subscription rights holders are entitled to subscribe one offer share for one subscription right (1:1 ratio) during the subscription period, from 18 March to 1 April.

title: Handle rights issues
body: Interim shares represent offer shares until 9 April, when the interim shares are exchanged for company shares.

title: Handle rights issues
body: Before proceeding, make sure you have created the securities (company share, subscription right and interim share (if used)) in the system. In the example case used here they would be ENEDO FH (the regular company share of type Equity), ENEDOU01 FH (the subscription right of type Entitlements) and ENEDON01 FH (the interim share of type Equity).

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Registration of subscription rights

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: This step can be done as either Issue or Exchange type corporate action, depending on how you want to handle purchase values of the subscription rights.

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: If you don't want to have purchase value on on the subscription rights, or you want to valuate the subscription rights with their calculated value, use corporate action of type Issue with the following details:

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Security: The security bearing subscription rights (for example, ENEDO FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Issued security: The Subscription Right (for example, ENEDOU01 FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Issue date: Ex-rights date (for example, 12 March)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Price/unit: Calculated price of the subscription right, or 0 if you don't want to have purchase value on the subscription rights. Note that the given purchase value reduces the purchase value of the original purchase lot of the share.

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Subscription ratio: The ratio with which you will receive subscription rights for every share you own (e.g. 1:3)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Transaction type: Subscription rights issue (C), SRIC, if you had purchase value, or Subscription rights issue, SRI, if you didn't have purchase value

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: If you want to valuate the subscription rights as percentage of original purchase lot's purchase price, use corporate action of type Exchange with the following details:

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Removed security: The security bearing subscription rights (for example, ENEDO FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Exchange date: Ex-rights date (for example, 12 March)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: Transaction type: Subscription rights issue (C), SRIC

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: New security: The Subscription Right (for example, ENEDOU01 FH)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: New security Exchange ratio: The ratio with which you will receive subscription rights for every share you own (e.g. 1:3)

title: Registration of subscription rights
body: New security Share: The percentage of the original purchase lot's purchase price you want to use for the purchase price of the subscription right. For example, if you have a purchase lot with purchase value of 2000 EUR and input 10 as the percentage, the subscription rights assigned to that purchase lot get the total purchase value of 200 EUR and the purchase value of the original lot is reduced to 1800 EUR.

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscribe for shares

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Create a new corporate action of type Subscription with the following details:

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Security: The Subscription Right (for example, ENEDOU01 FH)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Issued security: The Interim Share (for example, ENEDON01 FH), or the company share, if no interim shares are used

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscription/Payment date: Self explanatory (for example, 1 April)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscription price: Self explanatory (for example, 0.2)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Subscription ratio: The ratio with which you will receive shares for every subscription right (for example, 1:1)

title: Subscribe for shares
body: Transaction type: Exercise subscription right (C),SUBSC or Exercise subscription right, SUBS, depending on whether you selected SRIC or SRI in the earlier step

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Exchange interim shares

title: Exchange interim shares
body: This step is only needed if the interim shares are used. If the subscription rights were exchanged directly for the company shares, you can skip this step.

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Create a new corporate action of type Subscription with the following details:

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Security: The Interim Share (for example, ENEDON01 FH)

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Issued security: The company share (for example, ENEDO FH)

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Subscription/Payment date: The date on which the interim shares are exchanged for the company shares (for example, 9 April)

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Subscription price: 0

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Subscription ratio: 1:1

title: Exchange interim shares
body: Transaction type: Exchange (issue), EXCHISS

title: Exchange interim shares
body: The Exchange (issue) transaction type is used instead of Exchange to get the purchase value add up correctly

title: Mass-generate coupons and expirations
body: You can mass-generate coupon payments and expirations on bonds, and you can run the process yourself or schedule it to run at specific intervals (for example, every day). When you mass-generate coupons or expirations, the FA system creates corresponding corporate actions. Note that for coupons, the system can only create one coupon at a time per security (the next coupon), not all future coupons.

title: Mass-generate coupons and expirations
body: The following sections describe how to set up mass-generating coupon payments and expirations, how to create the corporate actions, and how to run or schedule them for later.

title: Step 1 - Define bond payment settings
body: Make sure the bonds for which you want to generate coupon payments or expirations for have defined payment settings in the Security window, Extra info tab in FA Back. For details on the available settings, see Extra info in FA Back reference.

title: Step 2 - Define the corporate actions
body: When you are ready to create the coupons or expirations, you need to define their information in FA Back:

title: Step 2 - Define the corporate actions
body: Go to Tools → Corporate actions → Create coupons and expirations.

title: Step 2 - Define the corporate actions
body: Define the fields in the Configuration window. For field descriptions, see Corporate action information.

title: Step 2 - Define the corporate actions
body: If you want to generate the corporate actions once, click Save and run. If you want to schedule the corporate actions so the system generates them at specific intervals, click Save and exit.

title: Step 3 - Schedule the corporate actions
body: After you define the corporate actions for coupons and expirations, you can schedule the system to generate them at specific intervals:

title: Step 3 - Schedule the corporate actions
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions and select the coupons and expirations corporate action process in the list.

title: Step 3 - Schedule the corporate actions
body: Click Add and fill in the schedule fields (for details, see Schedule processes in FA Admin guide).

title: Step 3 - Schedule the corporate actions
body: Click Save.

title: Corporate action information
body: You can define the following fields for the corporate actions:

title: Corporate action information
body: Enable scheduling

title: Corporate action information
body: An option to enable scheduling. Tick this checkbox if you want to use scheduling to run the corporate actions for coupons and expirations at specific intervals (for example, every day).

title: Corporate action information
body: Corporate actions to generate

title: Corporate action information
body: The corporate action types the system should generate (coupons, expirations, or calls). You can select multiple types.

title: Corporate action information
body: Reconciliation days profile key

title: Corporate action information
body: Run

title: Corporate action information
body: The date the system uses to generate the corporate actions. You can select "Never", "On coupon date (payment date)", "Transaction date (ex-div date)", or "Immediately".

title: Corporate action information
body: Time (coupon, exp. or call)

title: Corporate action information
body: The time when the system generates the corporate actions. You can define separate times for coupons, expirations, and calls. Define the time as HH:mm (for example, 15:32).

title: Corporate action information
body: Run generated corporate actions against

title: Corporate action information
body: The portfolios in which the corporate action transactions are created when the corporate actions are run. If the selected portfolios don't contain securities for which the corporate actions are created, no transactions are created in the portfolio.

title: Corporate action information
body: Security types

title: Corporate action information
body: The security types for which corporate actions should be generated.

title: Corporate action information
body: Days back

title: Corporate action information
body: Days forward

title: Corporate action information
body: Transaction types: Coupon, Expiration, Call

title: Corporate action information
body: The transaction type of the corporate action (coupon, expiration, or call). Define the transaction type for the corporate actions you selected with the checkboxes in Corporate actions to generate.

title: Corporate action information
body: Assignee

title: Corporate action information
body: Priority

title: Corporate action information
body: Due date

title: Related links
body: Bonds in FA User guide

title: Dividend
body: The dividend corporate action can be mainly used as a tool for recording dividends to your portfolios.

title: Dividend
body: The dividend corporate action can be used as a tool to create transactions in other situations as well, for example when running an expiration of a bond. The dividend corporate action takes the amount for the transactions from the position of the chosen security in the portfolio, and uses the dividend per share defined in the corporate action as the unit price in calculating the trade amount of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: The dividend corporate action can be recorded to the system through the Corporate action window with the following information (a star indicates a mandatory field):

title: Dividend
body: Security*

title: Dividend
body: The security the dividend is paid for. The amount of this security in the portfolio will determine the amount of the dividend transaction created.

title: Dividend
body: Currency

title: Dividend
body: The currency the dividend is paid out in. By default the dividend currency is the security’s currency. When the currency of the dividend is set to other than the security’s currency, the dividend transaction is recorded to your portfolios so that the dividend is calculated in the dividend currency and converted appropriately to security currency with the defined exchange rate.

title: Dividend
body: Dividend per share

title: Dividend
body: The dividend paid per share. This value will become the unit price of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: Annual meeting date

title: Dividend
body: The annual meeting date.

title: Dividend
body: Run based on*

title: Dividend
body: An option to run a corporate action based on:

title: Dividend
body: Ex-date. Define the ex-date and run the corporate action for all portfolio positions (settled and unsettled) that have a transaction date on the previous day or earlier.

title: Dividend
body: Record date. Define the record date and run the corporate action for settled portfolio positions that have a settlement date on the previous day or earlier.

title: Dividend
body: Dividend ex-date*

title: Dividend
body: (The field is shown if you choose to run the corporate action based on the ex-date). The dividend ex-date. The dividend is calculated based on the position amount in portfolios (settled and unsettled) on the morning of the specified date (i.e. the position after the previous day's transactions). This date will become the transaction date of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: Dividend record date*

title: Dividend
body: (The field is shown if you choose to run the corporate action based on the record date). The dividend record date. The dividend is paid out based on the settled position amount on the morning of the record date. This date will become the transaction date of the transaction created. Note that you can't see dividends that are run based on the record date in FA Fund Management.

title: Dividend
body: Settlement date

title: Dividend
body: The settlement date of the dividend, i.e. when the dividend is actually paid to the portfolio. This date will become the settlement date of the created transaction.

title: Dividend
body: Transaction type*

title: Dividend
body: The transaction type for the transactions to be created (if recording dividends, select "Dividend" or similar).

title: Dividend
body: A new corporate action is created with the OK button below the corporate action information. Remember to run the corporate action to your portfolio(s) in order to create appropriate transactions to your portfolios.

title: Redemption
body: The redemption corporate action allows you to mass-create bond repayments. This feature is currently under development.

title: Securities and market prices
body: The FA Platform allows you to record operations with different kinds of securities such as equities, bonds, or fund units as well as derivatives and FX contracts. To work with bonds, see Bonds. To work with complex securities like derivatives and FX contracts in FA, see Derivatives and FX contracts. For a list of security types in FA, see Standard security types.

title: Securities and market prices
body: You can create new securities or update existing ones in the Security window. See Security window in FA Back reference for details on adding information for securities. You can also search for and view securities saved in the system in the Securities view (see Securities view in FA Back reference).

title: Securities and market prices
body: You can also import securities in files or from a market data provider. To fetch security information from market data providers, see Get security data and Get extended security data. For importing securities in files, see File formats for importing securities and security prices in FA Back reference.

title: Securities and market prices
body: Security market prices can also be entered manually, fetched from a market data provider, or imported in files (see Manage market prices).

title: Securities and market prices
body: You can track and analyze security indicators such as duration, modified duration, convexity, and YTM for securities. For this, you need to define the key figures. See Key figures for contacts, portfolios and securities for more information.

title: Securities and market prices
body: To read about security configurations in the system, see Security preferences.

title: Loans as bonds
body: Loans are used to borrow money for investment purposes. A loan with regular interest payments is set up in FA Back as a bond. You can track accrued interest, calculate interest payments, and handle loan repayment.

title: Create a loan security
body: Create a loan security

title: Create a loan security
body: To create a loan security:

title: Create a loan security
body: Choose New → New security in the top menu. The Security window opens.

title: Create a loan security
body: Fill in the fields:

title: Create a loan security
body: Basic info tab:

title: Create a loan security
body: Code, Name – Create a code and name that contain information about the loan dates and currency.

title: Create a loan security
body: Security type – "Debt instruments (BOND)".

title: Create a loan security
body: Sub type – "DY: Money Market Instruments".

title: Create a loan security
body: Multipliers – "100".

title: Create a loan security
body: Issuer – Choose the contact of the counterparty.

title: Create a loan security
body: Extra info tab:

title: Create a loan security
body: Issue date – Loan start date.

title: Create a loan security
body: Issue price – "1".

title: Create a loan security
body: Maturity date – Loan end date.

title: Create a loan security
body: Maturity price – "1".

title: Create a loan security
body: Calendar (day count convention) – The agreed day counting convention.

title: Create a loan security
body: Frequency – "Once".

title: Create a loan security
body: Fixings for floating rate note – Start date and agreed loan rate.

title: Create a loan security
body: You can have multiple coupon periods both with a fixed or floating rate. The security configuration in the Extra info tab is the same as for a bond.

title: Add a loan to a portfolio
body: Add a loan to a portfolio

title: Add a loan to a portfolio
body: To add a loan to a portfolio, use a sell transaction. Enter an ID from another system or your counterparty in the Reference field and choose the counterparty in the Counterparty field.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: Create interest payments and expirations

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: Interest payments and maturity processing are handled in the same way as for bonds. To generate coupon payments and expirations, create and run a corporate action. An important note: use the "Expire short position (EXPSH)" transaction type.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: To create and run a corporate action, use one of the tools that suits you best:

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For a coupon payment on one bond, follow the steps in Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios.

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments on multiple bonds, import corporate actions in a file (see File format for importing corporate actions) and run them from the Corporate actions view in FA Back (see Record and run corporate actions to client portfolios).

title: Create interest payments and expirations
body: For coupon payments and expirations on all bonds in the system, use the functionality described in Mass-generate coupons and expirations.

title: Set up and run account interest
body: You can use the FA system to calculate, track, and run account interest for debit, credit, and other accounts. You can also use the account interest functionality to accrue negative interest on accounts that use portfolio credit (see Provide credit to your clients).

title: Set up and run account interest
body: Once interest is set up, the system calculates accrued interest every day using the following formula:

title: Set up and run account interest
body: Accrued interest

title: Set up and run account interest
Set up and run account interest
body: Account balance

title: Set up and run account interest
Set up and run account interest
Set up and run account interest
body: Base interest rate

title: Set up and run account interest
Set up and run account interest
body: spread

title: Set up and run account interest
Set up and run account interest
body: Number of days in a year

title: Set up and run account interest
body: In this formula, account balance is the balance at the beginning of the day, base interest rate is determined by an index or a fixed or floating rate, and spread is interest on top of the base rate that you can specify depending on the account balance.

title: Set up and run account interest
body: The following sections describe the process of setting up and running account interest in the Portfolio window and the Fees and interests view. In the first step, you set up account interest and start accruing interest on an account. In the second and third step, you define an interest run and execute it.

title: Step 1 - Set up account interest
body: To start accruing account interest, you need to specify interest details for the account:

title: Step 1 - Set up account interest
body: Open the "Interest details" section in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab and click Edit.

title: Step 1 - Set up account interest
body: Fill in the fields (for field descriptions, see Accounts in FA Back reference).

title: Step 1 - Set up account interest
body: Click Ok and then Save & close.

title: Step 1 - Set up account interest
body: Interest now accrues on the account. To track the accrual, select the portfolio in the Overview and see the "Accr. int." column.

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: To add the accrued interest on the account, you need to run it as a corporate action that creates an interest transaction. To define the interest run, do the following:

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: In the Fees and interests view, click New fee/interest calculation.

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: Select "Account interest" as the action type and fill in the fields in the upper section of the window:

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: Calculation date* - Account interest payment date (same as the previous account interest run date or later). The system runs the interest payment for interest accrued since the previous interest payment date (if available), the portfolio start-up date, or the date of the earliest transaction in the portfolio.

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: Transaction type* - The transaction type for the account interest transactions created when the run is executed. Select "Interest (INT)".

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: Memo - Notes related to your account interest run. You can use them, for example, to store additional information or to help with searching for previous interest runs.

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: Click Save & close.

title: Step 2 - Define the run
body: The interest run is now saved but not yet executed.

title: Step 3 - Execute or schedule the run
body: To execute the account interest run defined in the previous step, do the following:

title: Step 3 - Execute or schedule the run
body: Double-click the account interest run you saved to open the Corporate action run window.

title: Step 3 - Execute or schedule the run
body: In the middle section of the window, select the portfolios to run the interest to and fill in the tax rate and type of the interest transactions (You can set up default tax rates that the system selects automatically in Preferences - Taxation - Default tax rates).

title: Step 3 - Execute or schedule the run
body: To execute the run, click Run & close, preview the transactions, and click Accept and run. You can also schedule the run for later by entering a date and time and clicking Schedule & close.

title: Step 3 - Execute or schedule the run
body: The interest transactions are created with the status "Accepted". You can view the transactions in the Overview or Transactions view.

title: Re-run account interest for a specific date
body: You can re-run account interest for a specific date by selecting that date as the Calculation date when defining the interest run in step 2. When you execute the run in step 3, the system re-runs account interest for this date and creates a new interest transaction that replaces the existing one.

title: Related links
body: Fees and interests view in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: Provide credit to your clients in FA User guide

title: Pledge and unpledge positions
body: You can pledge positions or individual purchase lots to prevent them from being traded, for example, as a guarantee for a loan or as part of an incentive program. You can only pledge positions for securities that have no pending trade orders. Fees, account interest, and corporate actions can still be run for pledged positions, and they affect the pledged portfolio and its account. In the FA system, pledged portfolios are used to contain pledged positions. When you pledge or unpledge a position, the system creates transactions of your selected type in the position's original portfolio and the pledged portfolio.

title: Pledge and unpledge positions
body: You can pledge all positions in a portfolio by pledging the whole portfolio at once. You can also pledge positions one by one or specific purchase lots, in which case you need to create a separate pledged portfolio where the system moves the pledged positions. We recommend making this a subportfolio of the original portfolio. Before pledging anything, make sure you Set up pledging portfolios and positions (in FA Admin guide). You also need to make sure that the main portfolio uses the "Sum up values" method to aggregate positions from subportfolios (see Basic info in FA Back reference).

title: Pledge and unpledge positions
body: The following sections describe how you can pledge or unpledge whole portfolios or individual positions or purchase lots. You can also view what information is shown for each position or purchase lot.

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: You can pledge all positions in a portfolio at the same time. Note that you should only use this option if you know that all positions in the portfolio will be unpledged at the same time. To pledge the whole portfolio, do the following:

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: In FA Back, select the portfolio to pledge and open the Portfolio window.

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: Make sure the portfolio has at least one account defined in the Accounts tab and a contact defined in the Contacts tab (see Portfolio window in FA Back reference).

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: In the Basic info tab, tick the checkbox Pledged.

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: Click Save & close.

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: The whole portfolio is now pledged. You can also pledge the portfolio via the import functionality (see File format for importing portfolios in FA Back reference).

title: Pledge or unpledge a whole portfolio
body: To unpledge the whole portfolio, untick the Pledged checkbox in the Portfolio window, Basic info tab. Note that you can only unpledge the portfolio in FA Back instead of via import.

title: Pledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: You can pledge individual positions or purchase lots instead of the whole portfolio. For this, you need to create a separate pledged portfolio in which the FA system moves the positions you pledge. You can create multiple pledged portfolios and then select in which one you want to place the pledged positions.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Before pledging individual positions, you need to create a pledged portfolio in FA Back:

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Go to New → New portfolio to open the Portfolio window. Fill in the required fields (see Basic info in FA Back reference).

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Define at least one account for the portfolio in the Accounts tab and at least one contact in the Contacts tab (see Portfolio window in FA Back reference).

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: In the Basic info tab, tick the checkbox Pledged.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Click Save & close.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: The portfolio can now be used for pledging. You can also pledge a portfolio via the import functionality (see File format for importing portfolios in FA Back reference).

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: We recommend that you make the pledged portfolio a subportfolio of the portfolio from which you want to pledge positions. For this, do the following:

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Open the Portfolio window, Contacts tab of the portfolio from which you want to pledge positions.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Click Add subportfolios and enter the pledged portfolio you created in the Choose subportfolios dropdown field.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Click Add subportfolio under the dropdown field.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: Click Save & close.

title: Step 1 - Create a pledged portfolio
body: The pledged portfolio is now a subportfolio of the original portfolio. Note that pledged positions are still considered in limit analysis and rebalancing calculations, so we don't recommend rebalancing a portfolio with a pledged subportfolio because this results in trade orders in the pledged portfolio.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: After creating a pledged portfolio, you can pledge individual positions or purchase lots in FA Back:

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: In the Overview, select a contact and the portfolio you want to pledge from.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: Right-click the portfolio and select Pledging positions.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: Select a pledged portfolio in the drop-down field Transfer to. You can only select a portfolio in the same currency as the original portfolio. The system creates transactions in the original portfolio and the pledged portfolio you select.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: Define the Pledging date. We recommend selecting the current date. If you select a past date, any trade orders between that date and the current date are not taken into account in the list of positions.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: Select the positions or purchase lots to pledge (expand the row to see purchase lots). You can adjust the Pledging amount on the position level or select specific purchase lots. If you adjust the amount on the position level, the system selects the purchase lots from the oldest up to the specified amount. For details on information shown for each position, see Position information.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: You can also add a Description on statement which is applied to the resulting transactions.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: Click Pledge.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: As a result, the system creates the corresponding transactions and moves the positions or purchase lots to the pledged portfolio, along with the fee and tax of the position, relative to the pledged amount.

title: Step 2 - Pledge positions or purchase lots
body: You can also pledge positions via the import functionality, for example, if you need to move a lot of transactions into different pledged portfolios as part of an incentive program (see File format for importing portfolios in FA Back reference). If you import transactions into a pledged portfolio, you can use "Counter portfolio" to specify the original portfolio of the transaction. When the positions are unpledged, the system then knows where to move the positions. Before importing transactions into pledged portfolios, make sure you have the correct rights for importing transactions into pledged portfolios.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: To unpledge individual positions, do the following in FA Back:

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: In the Overview, select a contact, right-click the pledged portfolio, and select Unpledge positions.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: Make sure the positions or purchase lots you want to unpledge are selected (expand the row to see purchase lots). To keep a position or purchase lot pledged, untick the checkbox next to it. You can adjust the Unpledge amount on the position level or select specific purchase lots. If you adjust the amount on the position level, the system selects the purchase lots from the oldest up to the specified amount. For details on information shown for each position, see Position information.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: Define the Unpledge securities with missing original portfolio to field. You can only select a portfolio in the same currency as the pledged portfolio. This determines the portfolio where positions that have a missing or unknown original portfolio are moved. Such a situation can occur if you import transactions into a pledged portfolio without defining "Counter portfolio" to indicate where the positions originated from.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: You can also add a Description on statement which is applied to the resulting transactions.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: Define the Unpledging date.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: Click Unpledge.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: The positions you selected are moved out of the pledged portfolio and the corresponding transactions are created.

title: Unpledge individual positions or purchase lots
body: You can also unpledge positions via the import functionality, for example, if you need to move a lot of transactions into different original portfolios (see File format for importing portfolios in FA Back reference). To do this, make sure you have the correct rights for importing transactions into pledged portfolios.

title: Position information
body: The Pledge positions window shows positions and purchase lots that can be pledged in the selected portfolio and details about each of them in a table. The Unpledge positions window shows positions and purchase lots that are currently pledged in the selected portfolio and details about each of them in a table. All monetary values in these windows are shown in the portfolio currency. The following list describes the information available for each position or purchase lot:

title: Position information
body: Security

title: Position information
body: The security name.

title: Position information
body: Security code

title: Position information
body: The security code.

title: Position information
body: ISIN

title: Position information
body: The ISIN code of the security which identifies it on the market.

title: Position information
body: Amount

title: Position information
body: The number of units available for pledging.

title: Position information
body: Pledging amount

title: Position information
body: The number of units you want to pledge. You can adjust the amount on the position level or select specific purchase lots. If you adjust the pledging amount, the system selects purchase lots from oldest to newest until reaching the number you specified.

title: Position information
body: Pledged amount

title: Position information
body: The number of units that are currently pledged.

title: Position information
body: Unpledge amount

title: Position information
body: The number of units you want to unpledge. You can adjust the amount on the position level or select specific purchase lots. If you adjust the amount on the position level, the system selects the purchase lots from the oldest up to the specified amount.

title: Position information
body: Market value

title: Position information
body: The market value of the position in the portfolio currency.

title: Position information
body: Market value after unpledge

title: Position information
body: The market value of the position after it is unpledged in the portfolio currency, calculated as the market value of the pledged position minus the value of units entered in Unpledge amount.

title: Position information
body: Pledging value

title: Position information
body: The amount to be pledged in the portfolio currency.

title: Position information
body: Change

title: Position information
body: The unrealized profit or loss in the portfolio currency at the current market price.

title: Position information
body: On the position level, market value change is calculated as the difference between the total market value of the position and the aggregated purchase trade amounts of all its purchase lots.

title: Position information
body: On the purchase lot level, market value change is calculated as the difference between the market value of the individual purchase lot and its purchase trade amount.

title: Position information
body: Market value date

title: Position information
body: The date used to fetch the position's market value.

title: Position information
body: Original portfolio

title: Position information
body: The portfolio from which the position originates. When you unpledge a position, the system creates transactions in this portfolio. If the position has a missing or unknown original portfolio, the system moves it in the portfolio you select in Unpledge securities with missing original portfolio to.

title: Position information
body: Pledging date

title: Position information
body: The date when pledging occurs.

title: Position information
body: Unpledging date

title: Position information
body: The date when unpledging occurs.

title: Reconciliation
body: The reconciliation feature allows you to:

title: Reconciliation
body: Compare account balances and position data from an external source (for example, your custodian or a bank) with the data in the FA system to identify the mismatches. You can carry out reconciliation in FA Operations (recommended) or in FA Back. FA Operations is a newer app that gradually replaces FA Back for operations-related functionality.

title: Reconciliation
body: For reconciliation instructions in FA Operations, see Reconciliation. For reconciliation instructions in FA Back, see Create a reconciliation file and Reconcile a portfolio.

title: Reconciliation
body: Export positions from FA to reconcile or update data in another FA instance, or in a third-party system. For instructions, see Export positions from FA.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: The reconciliation flow in the FA system includes the following stages:

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: Obtain position or cash balance data from the bank or custodian.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: Upload the file or transfer it to the FA system automatically. For uploading the data in FA Operations, see Set up data sources. For uploading the data from M2Wealth and reconciling it in FA Back, see M2 Wealth.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: View the reconciliation result in the FA system. See Reconciliation in FA Operations documentation if you use FA Operations app, or Reconcile a portfolio in FA User guide if you use FA Back.

title: Reconciliation flow in the FA system
body: Fix mismatches by correcting transaction information.

title: Related links
body: M2 Wealth in FA User guide

title: Related links
body: Reconciliation and FA Operations in FA Product Description

title: Related links
body: FA Operations

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: There are two supported formats of reconciliation files in FA:

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: MT535 – If your custodian sends the data in the MT535 format, you can skip the reconciliation file creation and move on to performing the actual reconciliation (see the instruction in Reconcile a portfolio).

title: Create a reconciliation file
body: FA reconciliation file – If your custodian provides the reconciliation data in any other format than MT535, you need to transform the data into the standard FA format first.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The reconciliation file in FA format is a CSV file with the following characteristics:

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The default field separator is a semicolon. You can configure FA to accept files with a different separator. The separator must be only one character.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The record separator must be \r\n (CRLF).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: Numbers must use "." (point) as a decimal separator and no thousands separator.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: If the file contains non-standard characters, the encoding must be ISO-8859-1.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: File name can be any.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: The FA reconciliation needs to contain the following fields (use the field names as headers on the first row):

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: portfolio: Portfolio ID (as seen in the Portfolio window in FA Back).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: date: Date in the yyyy-MM-dd format (having two or more different dates in the file results in an error task and the file isn't processed).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: amount: Position amount or account balance.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: security: Any of securityCode / isin / tradeCode / updateCode1 / updateCode2 / updateCode3 is supported (either this or account is mandatory).

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: account: Account number.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: currency: Optional. It’s recommended to include currency in the reconciliation file - the system uses this information to match positions and cash accounts in different currencies, in case they have the same ID or account number.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: tradeAmountPf: Optional. Position purchase value in portfolio currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: tradeAmount: Optional. Position purchase value in security currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: marketTradeAmountPf: Optional. Position market value in portfolio currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: marketTradeAmount: Optional. Position market value in security currency.

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: Download the CSV file example:

title: FA reconciliation file format
body: fa_example_reconciliation_file.csv

title: Configure field separator for reconciliation files
body: By default, the reconciliation files must use a semicolon as a field separator. To use some other character, you need to specify it in FA Back settings:

title: Configure field separator for reconciliation files
body: Go to Tools → Administer → Data aggregation and open the Reconciliation tab.

title: Configure field separator for reconciliation files
body: Set the delimiter in the Delimiter field and click Close.

title: Reconcile a portfolio
body: This page describes how to reconcile data in FA Back. We recommend using FA Operations application for reconciliation. For instructions, see FA Operations.

title: Reconcile a portfolio
body: To reconcile position or cash balance data from an external source in FA Back, upload the file with external data, view the reconciliation results in the Tasks view, and correct the mismatches.

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: Upload the file with the data from your custodian:

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: Open Tools → Import file → Reconciliation material and select the file from your computer. Select the format (FA format or MT535) and choose if you want to perform the reconciliation based on the transaction date or settlement date of transactions.

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: View the results in the Tasks view, Reconciliation dashboard. If there are any mismatches, open the task to see details.

title: Upload the reconciliation file and view the reconciliation result
body: (Optional) View the portfolios with position reconciliation mismatches in the "Position reconciliation errors" dynamic portfolio group. You can find this group, for example, in the Overview.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: You can fix the reconciliation errors while having the window with reconciliation results open at the same time:

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Open the Reconciliation - Errors in the Portfolios view. Portfolios with errors have the "Reconciliation-Errors" tag and are listed in the view.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Choose the portfolio and click Reconcile → Positions at the bottom. The Reconcile portfolio window opens.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Choose the reconciliation date and click Reconcile. You will see the list of mismatching portfolio positions.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: While having the window open, correct portfolio positions in FA Back views if needed or use the Ignore to ignore an item.

title: Correct portfolio positions
body: Click Reconcile to re-run the reconciliation against updated content (and save ignored items), and show the new result.

title: Skip extra positions in FA system
body: By default, position reconciliation shows a mismatch if it finds extra positions that are present in FA Back but missing in your custodian's reconciliation file. You can change this behavior by excluding a portfolio or a security from reconciliation:

title: Skip extra positions in FA system
body: Ignore all extra positions in the specified portfolio – for example, if the portfolio contains positions from multiple custodians, and the reconciliation is done custodian-by-custodian. To set up this option, open the Portfolio window, Basic info tab and enable "Reconciliation: Ignore extra positions in FA".

title: Skip extra positions in FA system
body: Ignore extra positions in a certain security in all portfolios – for example, if the reconciled portfolios include unlisted assets that are missing from the reconciliation file provided by your custodian. To set up this option, open the Security window, Basic info tab and enable "Reconciliation: Ignore extra positions in FA".

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: I have my cash balance in the correct format, but the system says that the file amount is 0. How can I fix this?

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: Check out the decimal separator - it needs to be a dot (“.”).

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: My reconciliation gives POS_NFOUND errors, even if the portfolio has these positions. How can I fix this?

title: Questions about portfolio reconciliation
body: Check out the portfolio code: it can't have a comma inside the code.

title: Transactions
body: Transactions are used to handle and register operations with securities and cash, such as buying and selling assets, or depositing cash. Portfolio positions and cash amounts are calculated based on transactions. Once a transaction is accepted, portfolio positions and cash amounts are recalculated. You can create transactions directly (see Add transactions) or generate them based on trade orders (see Trade order execution). If you use FA accounting, bookkeeping entries are created based on transactions.

title: Transactions
body: The FA Platform has a set of transaction types for cash and security transactions (see Transaction types for cash transactions and Transaction types for security transactions). The transaction types are specific to security types (for example: coupon payments are specific to debt instruments). Some transaction types are shared between several security types (for example: buying and selling are available for several security types).

title: Transactions
body: Each transaction type has certain effects on the portfolio. For example, the cash effect of a buy transaction is to reduce the cash balance of the transaction account, and the cash effect of a sell transaction is to add to the cash balance of the transaction account. For more information about transaction effects, see Transaction types in FA Back reference.

title: Transactions
body: A transaction includes costs, fees, and taxes which you specify either as a percentage or an amount (see Fees and Portfolios view in FA Back reference). The effects defined for the transaction type determine if the costs, fees, and taxes are added to the transaction amount or subtracted from it. You can also extract the costs and taxes into separate transactions, for example, to keep track of costs in a separate portfolio (see Extract costs and taxes as separate transactions).

title: Transactions
body: You can also import transactions in files (see File formats for importing transactions and trade orders in FA Back reference).

title: Transaction types
body: In the FA Platform, each security type has a set of transaction types you can use. For a list of transaction types available by default, see Transaction types for security transactions and Transaction types for cash transactions.

title: Transaction types
body: Modifying transaction types is not recommended. Transaction types are defined to work in specific scenarios and changes can cause, for example, incorrect performance calculations. Instead of editing the transaction types, you can rename them or add new ones.

title: Transaction types
body: If you want to modify the name of an existing transaction type, you can use the Translate button in Transaction types (Preference, Transactions section). You should not modify the transaction type name directly.

title: Add a transaction type
body: You can add a new transaction type if the standard types do not include a suitable type for your needs. Use a similar existing type as an example. If you need to create a transaction type from scratch, contact FA support to ensure that no problems occur, for example, with profit calculations.

title: Add a transaction type
body: To add a new transaction type, do the following:

title: Add a transaction type
body: Open Transaction types (Preference, Transactions section) and click Add transaction type.

title: Add a transaction type
body: Fill in the fields and make sure all effects are correct (see Transaction types in FA Back reference).

title: Add a transaction type
body: Click Save.

title: Questions about transaction types
body: I get several different cost and profit transactions from my custody. I want to record all of them in FA. Can I add a transaction type for this?

title: Questions about transaction types
body: Yes, you can add a new transaction type for this. Copy the transaction type effects from a similar standard transaction type and link the new transaction type to the necessary security types.

title: Add transactions
body: You can create transactions from scratch or based on a portfolio position, for example, to sell or buy a security already in your portfolio. Creating transactions from portfolio positions is useful for coupons, dividends, and sell-all situations. You can also create transactions based on a position in multiple portfolios for partial redemptions or security switches.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: To create a transaction from scratch, do the following:

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: In the Overview, select the portfolio in which you want to add a transaction. If you select the portfolio first, the transaction is directly linked to the correct portfolio.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Click New transaction in the New menu (top left) and select a security type.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Fill in the fields in the Transaction window. For descriptions of the fields, see Transaction window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a transaction from scratch
body: Save the transaction.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: To create a new transaction based on the position in the selected portfolio, do the following:

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: In the Overview, right-click the position row and select New.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Select Transaction with position’s security and amount where portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date, or Transaction with position’s security, amount and trade amount where portfolio, security, amount, unit price, costs/taxes and trade amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Fill in the fields. For descriptions of the fields, see Transaction window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a position-based transaction in a selected portfolio
body: Save the transaction.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: You can create transactions based on a position in multiple portfolios, for example, to do partial redemptions or switches from one security to another using the reinvest option.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: To create transactions based on the position in multiple portfolios, do the following:

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
body: In the Positions view, search for a position to use as a starting point.

title: Add position-based transactions in multiple portfolios
