title: Check and create suggested trade orders
body: Create selected orders. You can find the created orders in the Trade orders view.

title: Check and create suggested trade orders
body: Create simulations.

title: Rebalance
body: Rebalancing helps you align your portfolio positions with your model – a model portfolio, investment plan, strategy or the shares you specify. The system compares portfolios with the target model and generates trade orders for positions that deviated outside the minimum and maximum thresholds specified in the model.

title: Rebalance
body: Before you rebalance, read about the rebalance logic below. Decide which rebalance method to choose: conservative rebalance, full rebalance, full rebalance including outstanding orders, exchange, invest cash, cover for cash, and model change (see Choose rebalance method). Once you chose the approach, select the rebalancing parameters and run rebalancing: define the affected portfolios, select the portfolio positions and accounts to include in the run, and specify the rebalancing and trade order generation parameters. See the instructions in Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio, Rebalance portfolios against an investment plan , Rebalance portfolios against a strategy and the field descriptions in Rebalance window.

title: Rebalance logic
body: When a portfolio is rebalanced, the system creates the trade orders based on the following logic.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Estimates the excess cash by checking if the portfolio's account balance is above the share of cash in the model. The estimation includes the accounts you chose and the cash from sells, if chosen.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Compares portfolio positions to the model:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Calculates the difference for each position in portfolio currency.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Calculates the number of units you would need based on the difference in portfolio currency and the market price on the selected date. Number of shares is calculated with as many decimals as defined in security type preferences, or overridden with the security block size.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Creates trade orders:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Buy trade orders are created first. Then the system creates sell trade orders. Buy trade orders are created, from largest to smallest, as long as there is excess cash in the portfolio. The last trade order might be only partially fulfilled. Sell trade orders are created with the same logic: from largest to smallest, until the target cash balance is reached.

title: Rebalance logic
body: If the difference per position measured in portfolio currency doesn't match a whole number of units (see the previous step), the system adjusts the trade orders following the logic defined in the rebalancing settings in FA Back preferences. Trade orders are recalculated based on:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Amount (using the calculated number of units and difference, and recalculating the unit price)

title: Rebalance logic
body: Trade amount (using the calculated number of units and unit price, and recalculating the trade amount)

title: Rebalance logic
body: For details, see "Create trade orders based on trade amount" and "Create trade orders based on trade amount" in Rebalancing preferences in FA Back)

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: A strategy sets the target per allocation share (not per position). When rebalancing against strategy, FA system calculates the asset type share in the portfolio. If this asset type is below or above the target, the system suggests buys or sells for the securities in the asset type. If an asset type is missing from the portfolio (for example, the strategy requires 10% Finnish stocks but the portfolio doesn't have any), the system suggests equally-sized trade orders for each security in the missing asset type from your buy list.

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing doesn't adjust holdings within the asset type. For example, if Finnish holdings in the portfolio are represented by one security, rebalancing considers this sufficient. It doesn't suggest sells to buy other Finnish stocks from the buy list.

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing works only for equity portfolios. It should not be used with funds and ETFs that are allocated to several asset types (for example, a fund security can be allocated as 70% US and 30% Canada).

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: To learn more, see Rebalance portfolios against a strategy.

title: Rebalancing portfolio cash
body: To keep portfolio's cash on a certain level, include the currency security as a position in the target. For example, if you have EUR accounts in your portfolio and want to have 1% cash in euros, add the currency security EUR with a target share of 1%.

title: Rebalancing portfolio cash
body: For the system-wide settings related to accounts and cash buffers in rebalancing, see Rebalancing preferences in FA Back.

title: Available cash for buys
body: You can define if you want to create buy trade orders only with available cash or use the cash received from sells as well (see Choose rebalance method). If you use the cash from sells, you can define the share of sells to be used for buys, to make sure you have some cash buffer if the prices fluctuate. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Available cash for buys
body: Cash from existing outstanding trade orders can also be used for buys (see Choose rebalance method).

title: Market prices
body: Rebalancing uses market prices and FX rates available in FA platform, picking up the latest values in relation to the selected rebalancing date. You can choose to use the 15-minute delayed market prices from your market data provider. To do this, edit preferences in FA Back: see Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Trade orders: based on amount or number of units
body: The system adjusts the trade amount or the number of units in the trade order if they don't match (for example, you need to buy for 300€, the unit price is 80€, and the security is traded in whole units). You can choose to create trade orders based on trade amount or number of units in the settings (see Rebalancing preferencesin FA Back).

title: Trade orders: based on amount or number of units
body: The number of units in the trade order is calculated with the number of decimals defined in security type preferences in FA Back, or taken from the security's block size (if it is specified).

title: Trade orders: based on amount or number of units
body: To prevent the creation of small trade orders when the investment portfolio only slightly deviates from the target, you can set the minimum trade order amount when you rebalance.

title: Selling an entire position
body: Rebalancing recognizes when you sell out the entire position by removing it from the target. In this case:

title: Selling an entire position
body: The minimum trade amount of the orders has no effect - the sell orders are generated without size restrictions.

title: Selling an entire position
body: The amount of the order isn't adjusted, but corresponds with the current position amount in the portfolio.

title: Selling an entire position
body: If rebalancing is restricted to accounts, entire positions are not sold unless there is "room to sell" based on the target cash balance.

title: Selling an entire position
body: Rebalancing marks such trade orders by creating them with a separate transaction type, as configured in "Select the transaction type used for trade orders when selling an entire position" in Rebalancing preferences (see Rebalancing). Rebalancing creates these trade orders as unit-based.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: You can include future contracts in the target. Rebalancing of future contracts depends on the security type settings defined in FA Back (Preference - Securities - Security types).

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: If the Future contract setting is set to "Yes - charge cost later": Buying a future based on the rebalance target share doesn't deduct the available cash.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: If the Future contract setting is set to "Yes - charge cost immediately": Buying a future based on the rebalance target share deducts costs from the available cash, if you choose to apply fees to trade orders when you rebalance.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: For both options, selling a future doesn't add to the available cash if one of the options for using cash from sells is used.

title: Collateral in rebalancing
body: To manage collateral in rebalancing, transfer collateral positions from the main portfolio into a locked sub-portfolio. When rebalancing the main portfolio, the collateral positions from the sub-portfolio are taken into account when determining how much to buy or sell in total, but the collateralized positions in the locked sub-portfolio are not touched.

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: To rebalance portfolios and positions, make sure you have:

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: Rebalance preferences defined in FA Back (see in Rebalancing).

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: Rebalance model (model portfolio, investmetn plan or strategy) set up in FA Back (see Investment objectives). Rebalance model is not required – you can also define the target values ad hoc when you rebalance.

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: For strategy rebalancing, the buy list of securities linked to investment portfolios. Buy list is used to add more positions in the asset type. To learn more about creating a buy list, see Rebalance portfolios against a strategy.

title: Rebalance portfolios in FA Invest
body: Rebalancing in FA Invest includes the following steps:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: To start the rebalancing, set up the table to view current positions and target values:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Open the portfolios in the PnL view. Click the Rebalance positions button next to the portfolio group, portfolio or position you want to rebalance.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Choose the model to use for rebalancing:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Base for rebalancing

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Base for the rebalance target:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Model portfolio, investment plan or strategy linked to the portfolio.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Current positions – current portfolio positions that you can adjust to create target shares.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Asset group

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: The asset group of the strategy that you want to use for rebalancing. This option is shown if you chose strategy as a base.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Include all positions from model

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Show the buy list positions with zero amounts that can be adjusted. This option is shown if you chose strategy as a base.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Once you chose the base for rebalancing, you can see the Position details and Model details sections showing the current and model shares.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Set up the table to group current and target values and show the relevant columns:

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Group positions in the table: click Columns on the right and drag the grouping parameter (for example, security type or asset type) to the top of the table.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Choose the columns you want to view, for example, Share of pf. % in Position details and columns in the Model details section.

title: Set up positions table and choose the model
body: Now you can see the current positions and the model shares in the rebalance table. You can proceed to choosing rebalance method and defining other rebalance options.

title: Choose rebalance method
body: Decide which rebalance method you want to use.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: With conservative rebalance, you can buy only with the cash in the portfolio account. You can realign the portfolio with the model in two rounds. In the first round, the system sells the excess positions above the target and buys with the available cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys more with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect conservative rebalance in the following way:

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Buy trade orders reduce the available cash for buys.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you need to buy something but you already have a buy trade order, or if you need to sell but already have a sell trade order, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: Example: You need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Conservative (buy only with extra cash in portfolio)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Conservative rebalance: buy with current cash
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Current cash only" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: With full rebalance, you can buy securities with available cash and the cash expected from suggested sells. This method calculates buys based on the estimated cash you will have after executing suggested sales with the latest market prices. With full rebalance, you can realign portfolios against the target in one go.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect full rebalancing in the following way:

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Buy trade orders reduce the available cash for buys.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you need to buy something but you already have a buy trade order, or if you need to sell but already have a sell trade order, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: Example: You need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: To apply the full rebalance method, choose "Full (buy both with extra cash in portfolio and cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance: buy with current cash and cash from sells
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Current cash and cash from sells" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding orders, you can buy securities with available cash, expected cash from suggested sells, and cash from outstanding trade orders with a positive cash effect (all statuses except "Open"), such as deposits and sells. Full rebalance estimates available cash that will be received after executing all sells with the latest market prices.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected from executing these orders. With full rebalance including outstanding trade orders, you can realign your entire portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: To apply this method, choose "Full including orders (also buy with cash from orders)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders: buy with current cash, cash from sells and from orders
body: To apply this method, choose "Current cash, cash from sells and from orders" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance.

title: Exchange
body: With exchange, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. The cash received from sells is estimated based on the latest market prices.

title: Exchange
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Exchange

title: Exchange

title: Exchange

If you need to buy something but you already have a buy trade order, or if you need to sell but already have a sell trade order, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Exchange
body: Example: You need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Invest cash
body: With the invest cash method, you can only use the excess cash in your account to buy securities, without making any other changes. It calculates buys based on the available cash but does not involve selling any positions.

title: Invest cash
body: To apply this method:

title: Invest cash
body: Choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only buy with the excess cash you have, but will not sell anything.

title: Invest cash
body: Choose "Conservative (buy both with extra cash in portfolio" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window.

title: Invest cash
body: To apply this method, choose "Current cash only" option in the Buy with field when you rebalance and choose the account.

title: Cover for cash
body: With the cover-for-cash method, you can only use sells to address negative account balance without making any other changes to your portfolio. The rebalancing process only sells enough to cover the negative balance, or example after withdrawing fees from the portfolio, and prevents excess cash in the account.

title: Cover for cash
body: To apply this method, choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only sell to cover for the negative cash you have, but will not buy anything.

title: Cover for cash

title: Model change
body: With the model change, you can update your portfolio model by selling the securities from the old model and investing everything into the securities in the new model.

title: Model change
body: You have an option to execute a model change either as Conservative rebalancing or Full rebalancing, depending on whether you prefer to do it gradually or all at once. Regardless of the method chosen, rebalancing will sell off your old positions entirely and reinvest the proceeds into the new positions.

title: Define rebalance options
body: Rebalance options above the table let you control cash usage, as well as trade order size and fees.

title: Rebalance options
body: Buy with

title: Rebalance options
body: Cash to use for buys:

title: Rebalance options
body: Current cash only. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in two rounds. First, the system sells the excess positions and buys with the current cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys more positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Rebalance options
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance options
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance options
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance options
body: Cash from sells only. With this option, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. You can also rebalance one position and swap it for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest market prices.

title: Rebalance options
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance options

title: Rebalance options
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance options
body: Current cash and cash from sells. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in one go. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance options
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back for details.

title: Rebalance options

title: Rebalance options

title: Rebalance options

title: Rebalance options
body: Current cash, cash from sells and from orders. With this option, you can align the portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders. Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.Cash from suggested sells and outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance options
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance options
body: Use cash from accounts

title: Rebalance options
body: Accounts to use for buys if you select to buy with extra cash in the portfolio. This option allows you to keep your portfolio fully invested and exclude certain accounts (for example, accrued fee accounts) from rebalancing.

title: Rebalance options
body: "All accounts" – Use cash on all accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Cash accounts" – Use cash on the accounts marked as "cash accounts" in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Cash and credit accounts" – Use cash on cash and credit accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Default account only" – Use cash on the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab. If this account is a credit account, you can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance options
body: Filter out small trade orders based on

title: Rebalance options
body: The minimum size for the trade orders that rebalancing should create. The size restrictions don't apply if you sell an entire position away from the portfolio (see Selling an entire position). Set the minimum difference between the portfolio position and the model as:

title: Rebalance options
body: "Diff %pt" – The difference in percentage points.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Diff %" – The relative difference in percentage.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Trade amount" – The minimum trade amount in portfolio currency. Alternatively, you can define a Minimum trade amount for each of your securities in FA Back (see Security window).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Model min/max share" – The difference defined with the minimum and maximum thresholds in the model. Trade orders are created only if the position deviates outside of the minimum and maximum thresholds. The minimum trade amount for each trade order is calculated as follows:

title: Rebalance options
body: For "buy": ( target share - min share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance options
body: For "sell": ( max share - target share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance options
body: Positions that don't have the thresholds specified in the model are rebalanced without filtering when "Position is within min/max share" is selected.

title: Rebalance options
body: Apply fees to trade orders

title: Rebalance options
body: An option to calculate fees, or to estimate the effect of an upcoming fee when generating buy and sell trade orders. If a fee is calculated, the effect of the fee is taken into account when determining how many units you can buy with you available cash and how much money you get from sells. This allows you to estimate the effects of upcoming transaction fees more accurately. Fees are also saved in the Fees field for each trade order.

title: Rebalance options
body: "No fees" – Don't include fees in trade orders.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Portfolio-specific fees" – Include a transaction fee defined for the portfolio in FA Back (Portfolio window, Fees tab).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Fixed fees" – Include a fee defined as a percentage in the field available next to the selection.

title: Adjust target values
body: If needed, you can adjust the target values further by adding positions or editing values:

title: Adjust target values
body: To add a position in the list, click Add position. Select the security and portfolio and click Add. Remember that yo can add all securities that are included in the strategy buy list by selecting Include all positions from model .

title: Adjust target values
body: To exclude some positions from rebalancing, select the rows and click Exclude positions.

title: Adjust target values
body: To adjust target values one by one, edit the Target values section of the table.

title: Adjust target values
body: To adjust several position values, select the asset type positions and click Edit positions. Fill in the fields:

title: Adjustment fields
body: Column

title: Adjustment fields
body: The value you want to adjust:

title: Adjustment fields
body: Share of pf. % – Enter target position share.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Units – Enter target number of units.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Market value – Enter target market value.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Diff. share – Increase or decrease the target positions share the specified percentage (for decreasing, use the minus sign).

title: Adjustment fields
body: Diff. units – Increase or decrease target positions units by the specified number (for decreasing, use the minus sign).

title: Adjustment fields
body: Diff. market value – Increase or decrease positions market value by the specified amount (for decreasing, use the minus sign).

title: Adjustment fields
body: Value

title: Adjustment fields
body: The adjustment value.

title: Adjustment fields
body: Method

title: Adjustment fields
body: The option to choose how the adjustment value is applied to the selected positions:

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Apply to all rows" – Apply the value to positions.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute the value evenly" – Divide the value equally among positions. For example, distribute €1,000 across 5 positions to add €200 to each.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute based on current position" – Distribute the value proportional to each position's current market value. Example: Distributing €100,000 ("Diff. market value") among positions with values of €50,000, €150,000, and €300,000 adds €10,000, €30,000, and €60,000, respectively.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute based on model position" – Distribute the value based on the model shares. Example: Distributing €100,000 ("Diff. market value") in a portfolio of €1,000,000 to positions with model shares of 10%, 20%, and 20% adds €20,000, €40,000, and €40,000.

title: Adjustment fields
body: "Distribute based on portfolio market value" – Distribute the value proportional to the portfolio’s total market value. Example: Adding 100 units ("Diff. units") of stock to portfolios with values of €1,000,000, €1,500,000, and €2,500,000 increases units by 20, 30, and 50, respectively.

title: About FA Back
body: FA Back app is a portfolio management tool for professionals to manage all aspects of their day-to-day work. FA Back can be set up to exchange data with external systems via file transfers or APIs.

title: About FA Back
body: Main features of FA Back are:

title: About FA Back
body: Portfolio management. Maintain information about instruments, market prices, customers, portfolios, and transactions, including fees and taxes. FA Back automatically calculates portfolio positions based on the completed transactions, to ensure that portfolios are up-to-date.

title: About FA Back
body: Analytics. Analyse the portfolio figures and view the result as a table, graph or a pie chart.

title: About FA Back
body: Trade order management. Create, send out and execute trade orders to generate transactions for your portfolios. FA Back can be connected to a trading platform for exchanging trade order information.

title: About FA Back
body: Corporate actions. Create transactions based on corporate events for several portfolios at once.

title: About FA Back
body: Fee calculation. Calculate fees that affect multiple portfolios. FA Back saves the fee calculations you created and keeps track of the affected portfolios.

title: About FA Back
body: Rebalancing. Set a model portfolio and keep your investments within the investment plan.

title: About FA Back
body: Bookkeeping. Generate postings and accounting entries that can be sent to external systems for processing.

title: About FA Back
body: Reporting. Export data from FA Back as PDF or XLS, generate standard reports based on client’s positions and transactions.

title: About FA Back
body: Task management. Keep track of the task list for you and your team.

title: About FA Back
body: Utilities. Set up a dashboard that shows everything you need on one screen. If usual search is not enough, run SQL queries to search and aggregate your data.

title: Global app bar
body: The Global app bar allows you to navigate between different applications and access certain actions.

title: Navigating between applications
body: The Global app bar is visible throughout all FA applications. This allows you to see the applications you can access and navigate between them through a single sign-on.

title: Navigating between applications
body: At the top, the Global app bar lists all the applications you have rights to access. Click an application from the bar to navigate to it. The new application is opened within the same browser tab. You can also right-click an application from the Global app bar and choose to open it in a new browser tab instead, allowing you to easily open multiple applications within the same browser.

title: Navigating between applications
body: Access to applications is determined based on user roles: you can see an application in the Global app bar if you have a role that grants you access to that application. The Global app bar is visible in FA Front only if you have access to other applications in addition to FA Front. If you can only access FA Front (for example, you are an end-user logging into FA Client Front), the Global app bar is not visible.

title: Accessing global actions
body: Global actions at the bottom of the Global app bar are available in all applications. You can:

title: Accessing global actions
body: View notifications and save them for later . For details, see Notifications.

title: Accessing global actions
body: Manage tasks and workflows . For details, see Tasks and workflows in FA User guide.

title: Accessing global actions
body: Access Helpdesk – Open the front page of FA Helpdesk in a new browser tab.

title: Accessing global actions
body: Access FA Documentation – Open FA Documentation in a new browser tab.

title: Accessing global actions
body: Manage two-factor authentication – Open a new browser tab to manage two-factor authentication for your account.

title: Accessing global actions
body: Log out from the system – Log out from all apps. If you had another app open in another browser tab or window, it takes up to one minute before your access expires and you are logged out.

title: Managing your user account's two-factor authentication
body: Once you are logged into the FA system, you can use the icon in the Global app bar to manage two-factor authentication for your user account. For example, you can reset two-factor authentication for a new device by setting it up again here. For more information about enabling two-factor authentication, see Enable two-factor authentication in FA User guide.

title: Notifications
body: FA allows you to keep track of processes by sending global push notifications about their status. You can view the notifications in any FA application, allowing you to get updates about processes started in one application while working with another. Notifications are available for 30 days unless saved for later.

title: View and save notifications for later
body: To open Notifications side pane, click the bell icon in the Global app bar on the left. In the side pane, you can:

title: View and save notifications for later
body: View all notifications in the All tab or only notifications saved for later in the Saved tab.

title: View and save notifications for later
body: Filter the notification list by type (see Notification types).

title: View and save notifications for later
body: Only view unread notifications by toggling Unread only.

title: View and save notifications for later
body: Mark all notifications as read or mark individual notifications as read by clicking the blue dot icon next to them.

title: View and save notifications for later
body: Save notifications for later with the bookmark icon . Saved notifications appear in the Saved tab.

title: View and save notifications for later
body: Notifications can also contain an "Open details" link to the application from which the process originates. You can click the link to learn more about what occurred in the process.

title: Notification types
body: The following notification types are available:

title: Notification types
body: Success. The process was completed successfully.

title: Notification types
body: Info. Information about the process.

title: Notification types
body: Warning. The process produced a warning.

title: Notification types
body: Error. The process failed.

title: Top menu
body: The top menu is a toolbar at the top of the page. It allows you to access many functionalities of the FA system using the drop-down menus on the left or the icons on the right side of the toolbar.

title: New
body: The New menu allows you to manually create something new into the system.

title: New
body: New report generates a new report from the Report window.

title: New
body: New contact creates a new contact in the Contact window.

title: New
body: New portfolio creates a new portfolio in the Portfolio window.

title: New
body: New security creates a new security in the Security window.

title: New
body: New transaction creates a new transaction in the Transaction window (choose the security type of the transaction from the menu - the available security types are listed in the order defined in Preferences - Security types).

title: New
body: New trade order creates a new trade order in the Trade order window (choose the security type of the trade order from the menu - the available security types are listed in the order defined in Preferences - Security types).

title: New
body: New corporate action creates a new corporate action in the Corporate action window.

title: New
body: New contract creates a new contract in the Contract window.

title: Tools
body: The Tools menu allows you to launch various kinds of standard and custom processes. The processes include:

title: Tools
body: Administering the FA system.

title: Tools
body: Creating coupons and expirations, paydowns, and securities from outside sources.

title: Tools
body: Launching fee calculations and monitoring processes.

title: Tools
body: Importing files and sending documents.

title: Tools
body: Creating contacts.

title: Tools
body: Realizing profits and losses on FX contracts.

title: Tools
body: Synchronizing the FA system.

title: Update
body: The Update menu allows you to recalculate portfolio report data outside the schedule set in Preference for a selected portfolio or all portfolios. Actions within the Update menu are logged (see FA audit logs in FA Admin Console).

title: Update
body: For more information about portfolio report recalculation, see Report data calculation in FA Admin guide.

title: Import
body: The Import menu allows you to import data into the FA system by uploading files from your computer. For more information about importing and the import formats, see Importing.

title: Menu icons
body: The following options are available at the top right of the menu:

title: Menu icons
body: Click to select the language of the user interface (English, Finnish, or Swedish). The language selection only affects the user interface for your user and is remembered the next time you log in. You can also change the default language of the user interface for all users (see General).

title: Menu icons
body: Click to access the FA Documentation site.

title: Menu icons
body: Click to view what version of FA Back you are currently running and see the highlights of the latest major version released. Your current version number is in the title of the window that opens.

title: Menu icons
body: Click to log out of the FA system.

title: Navigation levels
body: Navigation on the left allows you to browse through your views.

title: Navigation levels
body: The navigation supports up to three different levels: you can minimize your regular navigation into a list of icons through << at the bottom. You can open a second navigation level through the arrow next to each menu item. This extended navigation allows you to access all the searches tabs you have saved on all your views.

title: Navigation levels
body: Your selection of the navigation levels is remembered for the next time you log in - the navigation is opened with the level (icons, regular or extended) you were using the previous time.

title: Search options
body: Search options

title: Saving search views
body: You can customize your Contacts, Portfolios, Securities, Transactions, Trade orders, Positions, Customers, Analytics, or Bookkeeping views by saving your search criteria for later use.

title: Saving search views
body: You can use all the saved searches in the Dashboard view. Every time you open a saved search view, the search is performed again to show an up-to-date search result.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Saved views can be defined for your use only, or they can be shared with either everyone with access to the system or with everyone in a specific user group. For example, you can create shared views for everyone in the company to use, or separate views for back office and admin users, based on their usage and needs. You can save searches only for yourself to customize your own views.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: To manage your views, use the buttons in the upper-right corner of the view. You can save a new view with the + sign. To create a view, you need to define:

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Name of the view shown as the tab name on the top.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Sharing options:

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Not shared – The view is saved only for you to use.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Shared with everyone – The view is saved for everyone to use.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Shared with group xx – The view is saved for the users in a specific user group. The list of groups includes user roles assigned in the FA Admin Console app (see User management view in FA Admin Console).

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: Shared with role xx – The view is saved for the users with a user role defined on the system level.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: The OK button saves the view and adds it as a new tab in alphabetical order.

title: Saving and sharing search views
body: To modify or delete the view, use the buttons in the upper-right corner of the window. To modify the saved search criteria, make a new search and modify the view to save the new criteria.

title: Default search views
body: Once you saved a search on one of the search views, you can choose your default search for each view. The default view is specific to your user. You can choose any of your saved searches as your default with the icon at the top of the view on the right. Your default search appears as the first tab on the view. It's shown every time you access the view. This provides you with further customization opportunities: all search views support selecting the default search that will be shown every time you access the view. This allows you to access the information you search most often, by saving your most frequently used searches as your default tabs.

title: Exporting the search result
body: You can download the content of search views as XLSX or PDF files. For more information, see Export data as XLS or PDF in FA User guide.

title: Dashboard
body: Dashboard

title: Set up a dashboard
body: By following the steps below you can set up your dashboard and make it your default landing page.

title: Step 1 - Save searches or install queries or widgets as a base for your dashboard
body: Make sure you have appropriate content available for the sections on your dashboard. To add new content as a base for your dashboard, you can:

title: Step 1 - Save searches or install queries or widgets as a base for your dashboard
body: Save searches on any of the search views available for you in FA. All searches you have saved on any of the search views are selectable as content for your dashboard. To get more content available for your dashboard, just save a new search on any of the search views.

title: Step 1 - Save searches or install queries or widgets as a base for your dashboard
body: Save queries in the Queries view. All queries saved in the Queries view are selectable as content for your dashboard.

title: Step 2 - Build your customized dashboard on the Dashboard view
body: After having prepared the content available for your dashboard, the second step is to build your customized dashboard on the Dashboard view. To build your dashboard:

title: Step 2 - Build your customized dashboard on the Dashboard view
body: Click the plus icon next to the sample dashboard at the top-left corner of the dashboard view to start setting up a new, empty dashboard from scratch.

title: Step 2 - Build your customized dashboard on the Dashboard view
body: Select the layout for your dashboard from the layout selection icon at the top-right corner of your empty dashboard. You can choose the layout from different alternatives, consisting of different amount of available sections.

title: Step 2 - Build your customized dashboard on the Dashboard view
body: For each section within your layout, select the content for each widget from the downward arrow icon at the top right-hand corner of each section. Refer to step 1 for the options to get more content available for your dashboard. You can also further configure the sections on your dashboard through the configure icon at the top right-hand corner of each section. Query-based widgets allow you to configure the format of your query, and to view the results of your query as different graphs.

title: Step 3 - Save your dashboard and select it as your default landing page
body: After you have build your dashboard, the third step is to save your dashboard and select it as your default landing page. To select your dashboard as your default board:

title: Step 3 - Save your dashboard and select it as your default landing page
body: Save your dashboard by clicking the plus icon at the top right-hand corner of your dashboard. Define a name for your dashboard and select whether you want to share your dashboard with others.

title: Step 3 - Save your dashboard and select it as your default landing page
body: Select your dashboard as your default dashboard, or the default board that will be shown when entering the view, by clicking the icon at the top-right corner of the dashboard.

title: Dashboard view
body: The Dashboard as the landing page for FA allows you to view the most relevant information directly when logging in to FA. Each FA user can define their own dashboard and own landing page out of the information stored in FA. Customized and personal dashboards ensure that you will be able to directly access the information most relevant to you when logging in or when accessing the Dashboard. See also Set up a dashboard for detailed steps on managing your dashboards.

title: Managing the entire dashboard
body: To manage the entire dashboard, use the following features available at the top-right corner of the Dashboard view:

title: Managing the entire dashboard
body: Saving dashboards . Once you have defined a dashboard, you can save it for later useuse. Whenever you have defined a new dashboard, remember to save it in order for it to be available for you when you return to the Dashboard.

title: Managing the entire dashboard
body: Selecting a default dashboard . Once you have defined a dashboard, you can use as your landing page. The default dashboard's content is always shown when you access the dashboard.

title: Managing the entire dashboard
body: Modifying the layout for your dashboard . By default, a dashboard layout is set to 2x2, or to four sections of the same size. You can select a different layout for your dashboard, consisting of either 3 or 4 sections of different sizes. You can choose the layout from 1, 2x2, 2x1, 1x2, or 3x1 - try out different layouts to get the most out of the content of the sections you have selected.

title: Managing the entire dashboard
body: Refreshing the content of your dashboard . Refreshing the dashboard allows you to see the latest and up-to-date content within all the sections of your dashboard, to take into account changes someone else might have made in the background.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: To manage individual section, or widgets, on your dashboard, utilize the following features available at the top right-hand corner of each widget:

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Selecting the content of widgets. For each individual section on your dashboard, select the content you want to view from the downward arrow icon on the top right-hand corner of the widget. You can choose from:

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Empty widget, or an empty section on your dashboard.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Widgets defined in Preference. Widgets allow you to extend and customize the content available on a section on the dashboard - contact FA for more details about custom widgets.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Any of your saved searches on the search views. Any of the searches you have saved on any of the search views are selectable as content for your dashboard. The saved searches are listed as View name: Tab name, allowing you to easily identify the search you want to select on your dashboard. Whenever accessing the dashboard, you are presented with latest and up-to-date search result on your search-based widget. To get more content available for your Dashboard, just save a new search on any of your search views to select it for your dashboard.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Queries saved in the Queries view. Saved queries are listed as other saved searches as Queries: Query name, allowing you to easily identify the query you want to select on your dashboard.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Tasks widget, or a task list for you to view and manage your tasks.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Maximizing widgets. Maximizing a widget with the maximize icon allows you to view the contents of the selected widget as a full-screen window. When maximizing a search-based widget, you are also able to use all the buttons and other functionality available for you in the corresponding search view.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Configuring widgets. Configuring widgets through the configuration icon allows you to change the name of your widget and to configure the format of your widget (only available for query-based widgets). Query-based widgets allow you to view the results of your query as different graphs - select the graph you want to use from the Format field, and define the contents of your graph in the Label and Value(s) fields.

title: Managing individual widgets
body: Refreshing the content of a widget. Refreshing a widget through the refresh icon allows you to see the latest and up-to-date content within your widget, to take into account changes someone else might have made in the background.

title: Extended search and quick search
body: The views in FA Back have two search options, extended and quick search, and you can switch between them. The extended search is set as the default search option (see General). We recommend using the extended search for better performance.

title: Extended search and quick search
body: You can also filter the content of the columns shown in the views. You can click Show all and filter any of the columns available in the view.

title: Extended search and quick search
body: In the Transactions and Trade orders view, you can calculate total sums for numerical columns by enabling the Calculate totals option. The system calculates totals for most of the numerical columns, but this can cause the search to take significantly longer.

title: Extended search
body: The extended search is available in every search view. You can use the extended search criteria to perform targeted searches and avoid searching through all possible results, making the process faster.

title: Extended search
body: To switch to the quick search, click Show quick search.

title: Quick search
body: Quick search is available in every search view. Quick search supports searching with three letters entered in a single field to fetch information.

title: Quick search
body: In most search views (Customers, Contacts, Portfolios, and Securities), the quick search works uses "contains" logic. The system finds matches if any part of your quick search criterion appears in the results.

title: Quick search
body: In the Transactions and Trade orders view, the quick search uses "exact" logic. The system finds matches if your quick search criterion appears exactly in the results. If you want to find partial matches in these views, you can use * or % in your search. For example, you can search "Nokia" (exact), "Nokia*" (starts with), "*Nokia*" (contains), or "*Nokia" (ends with), respectively.

title: Quick search
body: To switch to the extended search, click Show extended search.

title: Choosing columns
body: You can customize each of the search views by choosing the columns and the information you want to see on the search result on each view. For the Overview, the column selection is user-specific: when you choose columns for you to view, it doesn't change the columns others are viewing. On all other views, the columns visible can be chosen per saved view, and are the same for each logged-in user.

title: Choosing columns
body: The Select columns icon on the top-right corner of each table opens up a new window for you to manage your chosen columns.

title: Choosing columns
body: The Chosen listing on the right shows the columns currently visible in the view in the order they appear: you can change the order of the columns by dragging the column name to the desired place in the listing.

title: Choosing columns
body: You can add a new column to the view by choosing it from the Available listing on the left and by clicking the > button. Similarly, a column can be removed from the view by choosing it from the Chosen listing and clicking the < button. You can also add / remove several columns at the same time by selecting them by holding the Ctrl key.

title: Choosing columns
body: You can also search for a column by typing in to the filter field. The list of columns is filtered according to the criteria you type in after you move away from the filter field. In addition, you can double-click a column to move it from one side to another. You can also drag-and-drop a column directly from the Available columns in the place you desire to place it within your Chosen columns.

title: Choosing columns
body: You can save the changes made to the chosen column by clicking the Save button.

title: Choosing columns
body: If you have filtered the Chosen columns, once you save, only the columns currently visible are saved.

title: Available columns
body: In general, the columns available on each view correspond with the fields available in each window. For contacts on Contacts and Customers views, you can choose from columns that correspond with the fields available in the Contact window. For portfolios on Portfolios view, you can in addition to the fields available in the Portfolio window choose to view any column available for contacts as well. Similarly, for securities on Securities view, you can choose from columns that correspond with the fields available in the Security window.

title: Columns for positions
body: For positions on the Overview and the Positions view, you can find the columns available including columns from security, contact, portfolio and the columns described in Available columns for position listing.

title: Columns for transactions
body: For transactions and trade orders in Transactions and Tradeorders views and the transaction listings on the Overview and Positions view, the available columns include all fields from the Transaction and Trade order window, certain columns from security, contact and portfolio as well as the columns described in Available columns for transaction listings.

title: Selecting dates
body: Choosing a date into a date field is relevant in several parts of FA. The field is visible when creating portfolios, securities, transactions or reports, and in several views. The date field appears as a single date or as a date range with dynamic selections. You can insert the date to date fields with several different ways described below.

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: When you choose a date or a date range in FA Back, you can:

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Select specific dates. To do this, click the calendar icon next to the date field.

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Select dates from the dynamic options, such as "Previous month" or "Last 3 months". Dynamic dates stay always up-to-date. For example, if you save a report on the Overview or a transactions search on the Transactions view with a dynamic date selection of "Previous month", the saved report or search will always be shown for the previous month in relation to today.

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Dynamic options for date range are:

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: From beginning

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: D0: Current day

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: D1: Previous day

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: W0: Current week

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: W1: Previous week

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: M0: Current month

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: M1: Previous month

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Q0: Current quarter

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Q1: Previous quarter

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: H0: Current half-year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: H1: Previous half-year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Y0: Current year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Y1: Previous year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: YM0: Current year to prev. month

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last 7 days

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last 3 months

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last 6 months

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last 12 months

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Dynamic options for a single date are:

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Current day

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Previous day

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: First day of current month

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last day of previous month

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: First day of current quarter

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last day of previous quarter

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: First day of current half-year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last day of previous half-year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: First day of current year

title: Dynamic date ranges
body: Last day of previous year

title: Choosing a date from calendar
body: You can choose a date from the calendar icon next to the field: by clicking the icon, a calendar opens up next to the field. The desired date is chosen from the calendar. The calendar opens up showing the present month, and the default date selection is on the current date. You can open the calendar view also by selecting the date field and pressing the downward arrow key.

title: Choosing a date from calendar
body: When you choose a date from a calendar, the selected date is marked with a blue background. The present date is marked with a light-blue border. It is also possible to move through the dates of the calendar with the arrow keys: when moving with the arrow keys, the movements in the calendar view are marked with a black dotted border around the date. The date is selected either by clicking the desired date or moving to the desired date with the arrow keys and pressing Enter.

title: Choosing a date from calendar
body: The arrows at the top of the calendar view and next to the field showing the current month and year are used to navigate from one month to another. The inner, single arrows can be used to take the calendar view to previous / next month. The outer, double arrows can be used to take the calendar view to one year behind / ahead from the currently visible month.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: You can also insert the date in the field manually in different formats. For example, the date 1.6.2011 can be inserted in the following ways:

title: Inserting a date manually
body: 1.6.2011 or 01.06.2011 – Write the date in the regular format, with or without zeros before days / months.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: 010611 or 01062011 – Write the date without the dots between the numbers, either as ddmmyy or ddmmyyyy.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: 0106 – Write the date without a year as ddmm, when the date is selected from the present year.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: The date can also be chosen with abbreviations:

title: Inserting a date manually
body: d – The present date.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: d + number – The present day minus the amount of days indicated by the number (for example, d1 chooses yesterday and d2 the day before yesterday).

title: Inserting a date manually
body: m – The present date.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: m + number – Chooses the last day of the month that is determined by the present month minus the amount of months indicated by the number (for example, m1 chooses the last day of the last month).

title: Inserting a date manually
body: q – The current date.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: q + number – The last day of the quarter year that is determined by the present quarter year minus the amount of quarter years indicated by the number (for example, q1 chooses the last day of the last quarter year).

title: Inserting a date manually
body: y – The last day of the present year.

title: Inserting a date manually
body: y + number – The last day of the year that is determined by the present year minus the amount of years indicated by the number (for example, y1 chooses the last day of the last year).

title: Inserting a date manually
body: The inserted abbreviations are transformed into the right date format after you remove the selection from the field by clicking any other part of the window.

title: Selecting securities and transaction types
body: You can find fields for choosing a security or choosing a transaction type in several parts of FA Portfolio. For example, the fields can found in the Transaction, Report and Corporate action window, as well as in the Overview or Securities and Transactions views. The fields always function the same way regardless of where the field is situated.

title: Selecting a security
body: You can choose the securities from a drop-down menu, in which the securities are listed in an alphabetical order based on the security name. The securities are listed based on the security type in the order that is defined in the Preferences - Security types: for example, if the security type "Stock" is defined above the security type "Bond", the securities of the type stock are listed before the securities of the type bond. Within the security type, the securities searched are listed in an alphabetical order based on the security name. Also, the security code, ISIN code and security currency are shown after the security name in the menu.

title: Selecting a security
body: You can search securities by:

title: Selecting a security
body: Browsing the list in the drop-down menu.

title: Selecting a security
body: Searching for a security with the security name, code or ISIN code, writing the name / code or part of it in the field.

title: Selecting a security
body: Writing the whole name, code or ISIN code to the field when security is automatically selected.

title: Selecting a transaction type
body: The transaction types are chosen from a drop-down menu, in which the transaction types are listed in alphabetical order. Also, the transaction type code is shown in the menu. You can search transaction types by:

title: Selecting a transaction type
body: Browsing the list in the drop-down menu.

title: Selecting a transaction type
body: Searching for a transaction type with the transaction type name or code, writing the name/ code or part of the name in the field.

title: Selecting a transaction type
body: Writing the whole transaction type code to the field, which automatically selects the transaction type for you.

title: Overview
body: Overview allows you to manage your customer's portfolios, providing you with the tools to view customer's investments and access or modify all relevant information.

title: Overview
body: Overview consists of two sections. The tables on the left show the contents and transactions of a selected portfolio(s). The panel on the right allows you to change between selected portfolios and to view certain portfolio, contact or group information.

title: Overview
body: Overview is customizable to your user name, and all the choices you make on the visible sections are saved for your user name and remembered when you log in the next time. For example, whether the panel on the right is shown or hidden is remembered for your user name: if you choose to hide the info panel in your latest session, opening FA again will open Overview with the panel hidden.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: At the top of the tab you can:

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Search for the portfolio, customer or group you want to view on the tab. In the menu, the customers, portfolios and groups saved in the system with the status Active (Passive and Closed customers or portfolios cannot be chosen) are listed in the following order:

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Groups listed first in the >Group Name form.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Customers and portfolios are listed second in alphabetical order: customers in the form Customer Name (ID) and portfolios in the form Customer Name - Portfolio Name (ID). In the listing, the customer is shown first, below which the active portfolios of this customer are shown. Passive and closed portfolios are not shown in the listing, and passive and closed customers are listed at the end of the listing in alphabetical order only if they have active portfolios.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: The Other portfolios section at the end includes all the portfolios saved to the system without a link to a portfolio customer. These portfolios are listed in the form Portfolio Name (ID).

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Quickly modify the selected group, customer or portfolio with the edit icon .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Choose the date you want to view to portfolio contents for.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: The icons on the right let you:

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Refresh the contents visible on the Overview to take into account all changes .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Open the Report window to print out a report for your selection .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Export the portfolio contents/positions in a PDF or Excel file .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Select the columns the position information is displayed in - see the descriptions of the available columns at Available columns for positions listings.

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: Hide the Info pane on the right .

title: Selecting what to see on the Overview
body: You can use your browser’s back and forward buttons to browse between the selections you have made on the Overview during your session. Every time you select a group, customer or portfolio, your browser’s URL reflects your selection - as a result, the back button takes you back to your previous selection. (Available from FA 3.6 onward)

title: Positions
body: The upper section on the left shows the contents or the positions in the selected portfolio(s).

title: Positions
body: If you choose a customer or a group, Positions shows the total or aggregated content and positions of all the portfolios of the customer or in the group. The positions are based on calculating purchase lots of the securities in the portfolio: when modifications are made to the transactions in the portfolio, the contents shown are instantly up to date.

title: Positions
body: The positions in the portfolio are divided into Securities (further grouped by security types) and Accounts (further arranged into cash accounts, credit accounts, and other accounts). Below each section, you can find Securities total, Securities total inc. accrued interest, Cash accounts total, Credit accounts total, Accounts total, Accounts total inc. accrued interest, and Portfolio total.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Right-clicking the Overview allows you to select how positions are shown on the Overview:

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Show positions. By default, all the individual, security level positions are shown. However, you can also choose to hide the security level positions under the security type headers. To collapse positions, right-click the Overview and deselect the Show positions selection. To show the hidden positions, right-click the Overview and select Show positions. Collapsing the positions allows you to effectively view large portfolios. Whether the positions are hidden or shown is remembered for your user name: if you choose to hide the positions in your latest session, opening FA again will open the Overview with hidden positions.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Show extended position info. The Overview allows you to see the effect of unsettled transactions and unexecuted trade orders on your positions. Positions are highlighted with red and marked with a symbol to indicate that the position is affected by unsettled transactions (marked with a circle) and/or unexecuted trade orders (marked with a star). Moving your mouse over a marked row shows you more information on the effects, including the current position, effects, and the position afterwards. For accounts, the unsettled transactions are shown as upcoming cash flows, and for portfolio total, you can see the overall effect of your trade orders on your portfolio. This feature is by default enabled, but you can choose to hide the extended position information by right-clicking the Overview and deselecting the Show extended position info selection - to show the extended position information, right-click the Overview and select Show extended position info. See more detailed instructions through Extended position information on the Overview.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Right-clicking a position on the Overview allows you to perform the following features related to the position:

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Open security. Opens the position's security in the Security window, where you can view and modify the security information. The same functionality can be accessed by double clicking a position related to a security.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Open security's linked portfolio. Opens the position's security's linked portfolio on the Overview. This allows you to easily access for example a fund portfolio through a fund position. The selection is available if your position’s security has a linked portfolio, and you are allowed to access it in terms of limited visibility. If you want to easily see which positions have a linked portfolio, select Security linked portfolio as a column on the Overview. (Available from FA 3.6 onward).

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Open security information (URL). Opens the URL defined in the security information as a new browser tab.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Search positions from other portfolios. Makes a position search on the Positions view for all portfolios with the selected security and date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: New transaction/New trade order. Opens a pre-filled Transaction window to create a new transaction or new trade order based on the selected position. For account positions, you can create new cash transactions. Choose to create New.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Transaction with position's security and amount - Portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Transaction with position's security, amount and trade amount - Portfolio, security, amount, unit price, costs / taxes and trade amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Trade order with position's security and amount - portfolio, security and amount are pre-filled based on the selected position, and transaction date is set to be the current date.

title: Right-clicking a position
body: Processes. Launches any process against a position through the right-click menu.

title: Transactions and trade orders
body: The lower section of the Overview tab shows the transactions and/or open and executable trade orders in the portfolio (including trade order statuses Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Executed in the market and Settled in the market) - by default the listing shows both transactions and trade orders. A star in the first column indicates an open or executable trade order in the listing. The selection of whether to show Transactions, Trade orders or All can be made from the first drop-down of the search fields.

title: Transactions and trade orders
body: By default, the transactions are shown ordered by the transaction date, newest first. You can also change this order by clicking one of the column headers: the arrow next to the column header indicates that the transactions are ordered based on the values in that column. In addition, you can use the search fields to search for transactions, or to filter the transactions shown with the columns you have selected to be visible on the Transactions listing through the column selection icon - see also Available columns for positions listings.

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: You can also view only the transactions/trade orders related to a certain position or account. This is possible by clicking a position or an account from the position listing - after this, only the transactions/trade orders related to the chosen security or account are listed in the Transactions sections. When clicking a position/account, the following transaction/trade orders are listed:

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked security as transaction's security.

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked account as transaction's account.

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked security as transaction's second security (for example, if there are exchanges, those are shown when clicking on either of the positions involved).

title: Show transaction/trade orders related to a position or an account
body: Transactions that have the clicked security's linked security as transaction's security (for example, when clicking on a future cashflow position will also show the contract related to it) (Available from FA 3.7 onward).

title: Hiding transactions from the Overview
body: You can hide certain transactions from the Overview’s transaction listing. You can do this by marking your transaction as Hidden – hidden transactions still affect your positions, but they are not shown on the Overview’s transaction listing. This allows you to filter the Overview to only show transactions you need in your day-to-day work to get an overview of your client’s investments, while you can access other transactions through the Transactions view. This is especially useful for bookkeeping transactions, such as deferrals or value adjustments, which don’t affect how much you own, but only alter the position’s values for bookkeeping purposes.

title: Right-clicking a transaction
body: To Modify or Delete a transaction or a trade order, right-click it. You can select multiple transactions or trade orders by holding the Ctrl key. The changes are then applied to all of the selected items.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: The upper section on the left shows the contents or the positions in the selected portfolio(s):

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: If you have selected a portfolio or customer, the portfolio hierarchy shows the customer and all the portfolios of the customer. If the customer shown is marked as a contact in another customer's portfolio, this another customer and the portfolio are shown below the customer's portfolios.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: If you have selected a group, the portfolio hierarchy shows the portfolios within the chosen group, grouping the portfolios under their customers.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Your selection is shown with a blue background. Customers and portfolios are shown in alphabetical order based on the name.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: The portfolio hierarchy section is limited to show only certain number of portfolios, by default 500. You can configure in Portfolios Preferences how many portfolios are shown in the tree. The title of the section indicates how many portfolios the tree is showing if your selection exceeds the maximum. This is relevant if you select a group with more than the number of portfolios show, all of them won't be shown within the tree. However, the entire selected group is included when showing the aggregated positions.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Portfolio hierarchy allows you to perform certain actions through right-clicking a level in the tree:

title: Portfolio hierarchy
body: Open group / Open contact / Open portfolio. Opens the chosen group / contact / portfolio in the corresponding window, where you can view and modify the information. The same functionality can be accessed by double-clicking an item in the tree.

title: Portfolio hierarchy
