body: The fields available in the Trade order window mostly correspond with the fields available in the Transaction window - see Transaction window for a more detailed description of the available fields.

title: Trade order information
body: However, there are a couple of fields for a trade order that differ from the fields available for a transaction - find information on these fields below.

title: Trade order statuses
body: Trade order statuses

title: Trade order statuses
body: Trade order statuses differ from transaction statuses, and are linked to different logic and functionality than transaction statuses.

title: Trade order statuses
body: You can choose the status of your trade order from the alternatives: Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market, Settled in the market, Executed, Cancelled, Rejected and Expired.

title: Trade order statuses
body: Trade order statuses have the following functionality linked to them:

title: Trade order statuses
body: You can modify only Open and Accepted trade orders.

title: Trade order statuses
body: You can execute only trade order with statuses Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market and Settled in the market - a trade order has to be pushed forward from open / accepted to be executable.

title: Trade order statuses
body: While the Trade orders view allows you to see all trade orders, the transaction listing on the Overview shows only trade orders with statuses Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market and Settled in the market in the selected portfolio(s).

title: Trade order statuses
body: If you have enabled the extended position information on the Overview, you can see the effect of un-executed trade orders on your positions.

title: Trade order statuses
body: Transaction preferences allow you to define which trade order statuses are available for you to use - enable the statuses you need for your trade order flows to represent your trade order's life cycle.

title: Trade order execution method
body: The Execution method field is only available for trade orders (not transactions), allowing you to differentiate between unit-based and trade-amount-based trade orders. This allows you to explicitly state how your orders should be executed, meaning if you want to "fix" the units or the trade amount when executing the order - essentially, with unit-based orders you want to buy/sell x number of units, and with trade-amount-based orders, you want to buy/sell worth x amount of cash (available from FA 3.8 onward).

title: Trade order execution method
body: Bulking trade orders is only possible with the execution methods Not defined, Units, and Net trade amount (see Set up portfolios and groups for the trade order flow in FA User guide).

title: Trade order execution method
body: You can select a trade order's execution method from the following list:

title: Trade order execution method
body: Trade order execution method recorded on the trade order can be used in Trade order execution when executing the orders - you can execute each order with the execution method defined for them.

title: Trade order execution method
body: Example: difference between "Gross trade amount" and "Net trade amount" based orders

title: Trade order execution method
body: Gross trade amount based order to subscribe for 1000 EUR of Fund X shares, with 1% subscription fee, would result in a trade costing the investor 1010 EUR (incl. 10 EUR fee). Similarly, a redemption for 1000 EUR of Fund X shares with 1% redemption fee would result in a trade that pays the investor 990 EUR (after a fee of 10 EUR).

title: Trade order execution method
body: Net trade amount based order to subscribe for 1000 EUR of Fund X shares, with 1% subscription fee, would result in a trade costing the investor 1000 EUR (incl. 10 EUR fee). Similarly, a redemption for 1000 EUR of Fund X shares with 1% redemption fee would result in a trade that pays the investor 1000 EUR (after a fee of 10 EUR).

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Payment date field allows you to manage pre-paid orders - if your trade order has a payment date and the order matches the required criteria, your portfolio's cash is deducted on the payment date already based on a trade order, even when a transaction doesn’t yet exist.

title: Pre-paid orders
body: In order for a trade order to be considered as "pre-paid" and your portfolio's cash to be deducted based on the order, the order has to fulfil the following criteria:

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Trade order has a payment date

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Trade order is linked to a security (payment date is only available for security orders, not cash orders)

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Trade order is linked to an account (for the system to know which account's balance to deduct)

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Trade order status is Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market or Settled in the market (cash balance is affected when a trade order has been accepted and pushed forward but not yet executed)

title: Pre-paid orders
body: When utilizing pre-paid orders, the cash effect of the trade order is transferred from the order to the created transaction during trade order execution. The flow from pre-paid order to pre-paid transaction goes roughly as follows:

title: Pre-paid orders
body: A trade order is created for a customer to buy something. Customer is informed that (s)he needs to pre-pay for the order.

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Payment date is added on the trade order once the customer has paid it, and trade order is pushed forward from "Open" to "Executable".

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Customer's cash balance is deducted based on the pre-paid trade order.

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Trade order is executed. Trade order status changes to "Executed", and the trade order no longer has an effect on the customer's cash balance.

title: Pre-paid orders
body: Transaction created through trade order execution appears in the portfolio. The payment date recorded on the trade order was passed on to the created transaction, and the customer's cash balance is still deducted on the payment date while the security position appears in the portfolio on the transaction date.

title: Transaction fee in Internal info
body: The Internal info field for a trade order can be used to enter the transaction fee percentage for the fund subscriptions and redemptions. For example, for a 0.5% fee, enter: fee=0.5. To learn more about managing subscription and redemption fees for a fund, see Transaction fees for a fund in FA User guide.

title: Analyze pre-trade limits
body: Analyze pre-trade limits

title: Analyze pre-trade limits
body: When you are manually creating a new trade order or modifying a trade order in status "Open", the Analyze pre-trade limits button allows you to run an ad-hoc pre-trade limit analysis before actually saving the trade order. The limit analysis results are shown in the Limits tab.

title: Limits
body: The Limits tab lets you check if a new trade order would breach the limits set for the portfolio. The analysis takes into account the portfolio's current positions and all other outstanding trade orders. For more information, see Pre-trade limits analysis on open trade orders.

title: Limits
body: To run the limit analysis, click Analyze pre-trade limits (the button is shown only for the trade orders in the "open" status).

title: Limits
body: To view the history of limit checks, click .

title: Saving a trade order
body: Saving a trade order

title: Saving a trade order
body: Saving a trade order saves it in the system. A trade order doesn't yet affect your portfolio's content, but is a suggestion to buy or sell something. If you have enabled the extended position information on the Overview, you can see the effect of unexecuted trade orders on your positions.

title: Saving a trade order
body: At the bottom of the Trade order window, you can:

title: Saving a trade order
body: Save & close

title: Saving a trade order
body: Saves the trade order / changes made to the trade order information and closes the window.

title: Saving a trade order
body: Save

title: Saving a trade order
body: Saves the changes made to the trade order information.

title: Saving a trade order
body: Save & new

title: Saving a trade order
body: Saves the trade order / changes made to the trade order information and opens a new, empty trade order window for you to create a new trade order.

title: Saving a trade order
body: Save & new (copy)

title: Saving a trade order
body: Saves the trade order / changes made to the trade order information and opens a new trade order window prefilled with information from the trade order you copied. This function copies all other trade order information except for the External ID and Reference.

title: Trade order execution
body: Execute trade orders on the bottom right-hand corner of the Trade orders view you can initiate trade order execution in order to execute executable trade orders saved in the system.

title: Trade order execution
body: To execute trade orders, search the trade orders to be executed on the Trade orders view and start the process against the trade orders within the selection with the Trade order execution button. Alternatively, you can click the Trade order execution button without searching for trade orders, when the process is started against all available trade orders in the system.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The trade order execution for executable trade orders or a process for open trade orders is started with choosing the trade orders to execute.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The Executable and Open trade orders window list the options available: the Executable trade orders include trade orders with statuses Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market and Settled in the market, and the Open trade orders include trade orders with statuses Open and Accepted. The information of these options is divided into columns

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: Security

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The security of the trade orders.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: ISIN / Code

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The ISIN code (or if not defined, security code) of the security of the trade orders.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: Transaction type

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The type of the trade orders.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: Count

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The number of the trade orders, e.g. how many trade orders are includes in the option.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: Units / Nominal

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The total amount of the security of the trade orders.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: Currency

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: The currency of the trade orders in the form security currency => portfolio currency (for example EUR =>; EUR means that the currency of the trade order's security is EUR, and it will be executed in an EUR portfolio)

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: You can only execute or start processes for trade orders of the same type (buy / sell) and same security, with the same combination of trade order's and portfolio's currency: such combinations are listed as options in the executable and open trade orders. For example, you can execute simultaneously all buy trade orders of Nokia, recorded in an EUR portfolio, but you cannot include sell trade orders of Nokia or buy trade orders of other securities to the same execution.

title: Step 1 - Executable trade orders / Open trade orders
body: >> button selects the executable trade orders and starts the trade order execution for them OR selects the open trade orders and allows starting a process for them

title: Step 2 - Trade order execution
body: Once the trade orders to be executed are selected from executable trade orders, you can define the trade order execution information.

title: Step 2 - Trade order execution
body: Trade order execution allows you to define the information used in the trade order execution. Trade orders can be either executed with the information saved to them, or the trade order information can be overridden by defining common information used for all executed trade orders.

title: Step 2 - Trade order execution
body: The trade order execution automatically suggests the information used the previous time for the trade orders with the same transaction type: when executing similar trade orders, the system remembers the selections you made last time, and automatically suggests these to be used again. This facilitates trade order execution, when some information is pre-defined, and you don't need to define all the information every time.

title: Step 2 - Trade order execution
body: The execution information is divided into different sections, described below.

title: Date info
body: You can choose either to Use trade order date info or to Set date info. Trade orders are either executed with the information saved to them, or you can override this information and execute all trade orders with the same information by defining the Transaction date, Time, Settlement date and Payment date. You can also override only some information: by leaving one of the fields empty, the trade orders are executed with the trade order information for the empty field.

title: Date info
body: By default, if you selected to set the date info:

title: Date info
body: Transaction date and transaction time are set to be today and the time the execution was started.

title: Date info
body: Settlement date is set to a certain number of business days ahead of the transaction date. If the "Enable settlement date" has been enabled for the trade order's security, the number of days defined in "Settlement date" is used to calculate the settlement date, or if not defined per security, the "Amount of business days" configured in Transactions Preferences is used to calculate the settlement date. In addition to how many business days trades take to settle, the trade order's security's holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Date info
body: Payment date is by default empty, and by default the payment date set for the pre-paid orders is used for the created transactions.

title: Execution parameters
body: You can choose to either to Use price and amount from trade orders or to Define execution parameters. Trade orders are either executed with the information saved to them, or you can override this information and execute all trade orders with the same information by defining the Price, FX rate, Fee % and Cost type, and choosing the execution Method. You can also override only some information: by leaving one of the fields empty, the trade orders are executed with the trade order information for the empty field.

title: Execution parameters
body: The execution parameters available are:

title: Execution parameters
body: Price - define the unit price you want to execute your orders with. This is the price you executed the trade in the market - depending on the selected method, either the units or trade amount is re-calculated with this unit price. You can easily use the latest available Price during execution by typing in a question mark (?) - this fetches the latest available price for the selected Transaction date, or current date if you didn’t choose to Set date info (available from FA 3.9 forward).

title: Execution parameters
body: FX rate - define the FX rate you want to execute your orders with. You can easily use the latest available FX rate during execution by typing in a question mark (?) - this fetches the latest available FX rate for the selected Transaction date, or current date if you didn’t choose to Set date info (available from FA 3.9 forward).

title: Execution parameters
body: Method - select the execution method, i.e. whether the units or trade amount is re-calculated based on the unit price you entered. Options available are:

title: Execution parameters
body: Calculate amount fixes the trade amount defined for the trade order, applies the unit price defined during execution, and re-calculates amount (i.e. units). If you have configured your security type so that you cannot trade with fractions of shares, the logic is conservative, rounding the number of units down - as a result, your trade amount might be smaller than you originally requested, but never larger (e.g. you want to buy worth 100€ and enter unit price 33€ during execution -> calculated amount 3 ->; transaction 3 * 33€ = 99€). If you calculate fees during the execution, those are taken into account so that total trade amount including fee stays the same.

title: Execution parameters
body: Calculate trade amount fixes the amount (i.e. units) defined for the trade order, applies the unit price defined during execution, and re-calculates trade amount. If you calculate fees during the execution, those are taken into account so that they are added / subtracted from the calculated trade amount.

title: Execution parameters
body: Use execution method uses the execution method stored on each trade order to determine how each order should be executed. With this option, you can execute unit-based and trade-amount-based orders on the same go, and the parameters you define might be applied differently on different orders (i.e. for some orders, execution calculates amount and for some order, execution calculates trade amount). See below for examples! (Available from FA 3.8 onward).

title: Execution parameters
body: Fee % - define a fee percentage if you want the execution to automatically calculate a fee on your transaction. Fee is stored into the "Fee" field in the Transaction window, i.e. into the lower fee field in the window (cost1). The fee is calculated as a percentage from the price of your transaction (price = units * unit price), and the effect varies a bit depending on the selected execution method (for calculate amount, total trade amount including fee stays the same, and for calculate trade amount, units are fixed and trade amount is calculated as units * price +/ fee). If your trade order had a fee in the "Fee" field, defining a percentage here will override the fee - if you leave the fee % empty, then the fees on your trade order will be carried over to the transaction. This only affects the "Fee" field - "Credit fee" is always directly carried to the transaction if it has been defined on the order.

title: Execution parameters
body: Cost type - select a cost type for your fees, associated with the fee calculated during execution. If you select a cost type, the system will fetch a fee percentage with the selected cost type from portfolio's fee information (maintained in the Portfolio window) and calculate fees on the transaction with that percentage. If a fee percentage is not found from the portfolio with the selected cost type, then the fees are calculated with the "Fee %" defined in the execution parameters.

title: Execution parameters
body: Rounding type - select a tax type for "rounding error" if you want the trade order execution to calculate and record rounding errors on your trade-amount-based orders. Trade order execution supports "rounding errors" to ensure your trade-amount-based trade order’s trade amount matches to the decimal after execution. Rounding errors might occur when execution calculates units for trade-amount-based orders and updates values - rounding error ensures your order’s original trade amount remains untouched. See below for examples! Rounding errors are calculated if you select a Rounding type from the list of available tax types (add a tax type for "rounding errors" to be able to distinguish rounding errors from taxes) and recorded to the Tax 2 field of your executed transactions. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Execution parameters
body: Example: Rounding errors

title: Execution parameters
body: When you have selected a "Rounding type" (available from FA 3.9 onward) and you are executing a trade-amount-based order, the system calculates a rounding error to ensure the original trade amount of your order remains untouched.

title: Execution parameters
body: You have an order to buy with 100€ and your unit price during execution is 33,33€.

title: Execution parameters
body: -> you will get 100 / 33 = 3 units.

title: Execution parameters
body: With these units, your trade order is updated to 3 * 33,33€ = 99,99€, which is 0,01€ different from your original order.

title: Execution parameters
body: -> when rounding errors are enabled, execution calculates a rounding error of 100€ - 99,99€ = 0,01€ and records it into your transaction.

title: Execution parameters
body: With this, your trade order is updated to 3 * 33,33€ + 0,01€ = 100€.

title: Execution parameters
body: Example: Execution method

title: Execution parameters
body: When you have selected to "Use execution method" (available from FA 3.8 onward), your orders are executed the following way based on their execution method. You can see the Execution method of each order involved in your execution in the trade order listing at the bottom, allowing you to easily check how each of your orders will be executed (available from FA 3.9 onward).

title: Counter portfolio and counter transactions
body: You can choose to either to Execute trade orders directly or to Execute trade orders via counter portfolio. Trade orders are either executed directly, or you can execute the trade orders via counter portfolio by choosing the Counter portfolio, Counter transaction and Cash transaction.

title: Counter portfolio and counter transactions
body: This allows you to trade through a counter portfolio, and get all the required transactions in place automatically: for each "buy" your customer does, you can create a corresponding "sell to customer" in your counter portfolio, and optionally a separate "withdrawal" in your counter portfolio. Similarly, for customer's "sells", you'd create a corresponding "buy from customer" and "deposit" to keep your counter portfolio up-to-date.

title: Counter portfolio and counter transactions
body: If you choose to execute your trade orders via a counter portfolio, in addition to creating a transaction to the portfolio of the trade order, a counter transaction and a cash transaction is created to the selected counter portfolio. You can also decide only to do one of the transactions in the counter portfolio: counter transaction or cash transaction are created only if you fill in the corresponding field, and you can choose not to create them by leaving the field empty.

title: Account used for transactions
body: You can also select what logic is used when setting an account to the created transactions. This selection is available through the Account used for transactions field with the following selections. These options only pick up cash accounts from your portfolio - accounts not marked as cash accounts are ignored when trade order execution sets an account to the created transactions.

title: Account used for transactions
body: Use the currency account (or default account) to transactions. This option is by default selected. With this selection, the account of the transaction is set to:

title: Account used for transactions
body: The account set to the trade order. If an account is set to the trade order, this account is used for the transaction as well.

title: Account used for transactions
body: If "No account" is set for the trade order, then:

title: Account used for transactions
body: The account in the portfolio with the same currency as the trade order is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Account used for transactions
body: If an account with the same currency as the trade order cannot be found from the portfolio, then the portfolio's default account is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Account used for transactions
body: If no accounts can be found from the portfolio, then the shared accounts for the portfolio are used in the same order: by default setting the shared account with the same currency as the trade order, and if not found, then setting the shared default account.

title: Account used for transactions
body: Use the default account to transactions. With this selection, the account of the transaction is set to:

title: Account used for transactions
body: The account set to the trade order. If an account is set to the trade order, this account is used for the transaction as well.

title: Account used for transactions
body: If "No account" is set for the trade order, then the portfolio's default account is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Account used for transactions
body: Use the account of the trade order to transactions. With this selection, the account of the transaction is only set to be the account of the trade order.

title: Calculate accrued interest or accrual
body: Trade order execution considers the characteristics of bonds with accrued interest and funds with accrual through allowing you to update the accrued component on your bond or fund orders during execution. This allows you to efficiently use trade order execution also on these types of orders. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Calculate accrued interest or accrual
body: You can instruct trade order execution to update the accrued component through a checkbox:

title: Calculate accrued interest or accrual
body: Calculate accrued interest to transactions - check if you want to update the accrued interest of your bond orders during execution (only available when executing orders of the base type BOND). When checked, trade order execution calculates the paid / received accrued interest of the transaction (up to the settlement date of the transaction) if coupon and fixing information is defined for the security in the Extra info tab of the Security window.

title: Calculate accrued interest or accrual
body: Calculate accrual to transactions - check if you want to update the accrual of your fund orders during execution (only available when executing orders of the base type FUND). When checked, trade order execution calculates the paid / received accrual of the transaction on the transaction date if accrual information is defined for the security in the Market data info tab in the Security window.

title: Description on statement
body: Description on statement allows you to set a common description stored in the "Description on statement" field for the transactions and counter transactions created through the trade order execution.

title: Executed trade orders
body: Executed trade orders at the bottom shows the trade orders to be executed. If you chose to execute your trade orders with the information defined on the orders, you can modify the trade order information manually by modifying the Trade date, Time, Settlement date, Units/Nominal, Unit price, Cost or FX rate. By default these fields show the information saved on the trade order. You can also exclude a trade order from the execution by deselecting it from the executed trade orders listing.

title: Executed trade orders
body: << button at the bottom returns one step back in the trade order execution process, and >> button proceeds in the trade order execution process.

title: Step 3 - Market transaction
body: If you have selected to execute your trade orders via a counter portfolio, you can define whether the trade order execution involves a market transaction recorded to the selected counter portfolio.

title: Step 3 - Market transaction
body: The window is divided into two sections - if you have not selected to execute your transactions via a counter portfolio, only the transactions section is visible.

title: Market transaction
body: You can choose to either to create No transaction in the market, to Execute transaction in the market or to Execute market transaction per trade order. This allows you to create a market transaction / multiple market transactions automatically into your counter portfolio, corresponding to the counter transaction created to the counter portfolio based on the executed trade orders.

title: Market transaction
body: If you chose to create a market transaction, you can define the market transaction information. The market transaction definition automatically suggests the information used the previous time for trade orders with the same transaction type and same security: when executing similar trade orders, the system remembers the selections you made last time, and automatically suggests these to be used again. This facilitates trade order execution, when some information is pre-defined, and you don't need to define all the information every time.

title: Market transaction
body: The information to be defined contains:

title: Market transaction
body: Counter transactions - the type, total units, unit price, total costs, total trade amount and exchange rate of all the counter transactions to be created.

title: Market transaction
body: Market transactions - define the type, units, unit price, cost, trade amount, exchange rate and counter of the market transaction to be created. The market transaction is created to the chosen counter portfolio with the information defined here.

title: Market transaction
body: Difference - shows the difference in units, unit prices, costs, trade amounts and exchange rates between the counter transactions combined and the market transaction. The difference can be either positive or negative depending on the figures and selected types: the difference states the profit / loss in the counter portfolio when the counter and market transactions are executed.

title: Transactions
body: Transactions at the bottom lists the transactions to be created to portfolios from the trade order execution with the transaction information (the transactions based on the trade orders together with possible counter and cash transactions). You can see all the transaction to be created in the listing, and if necessary, return to modify the trade order execution information.

title: Transactions
body: << button at the bottom returns on step back in the trade order execution process, and OK button accept the trade order execution, creates the transactions defined and sets the trade order status of the executed trade orders as Executed.

title: Step 4 - Executed transactions
body: After you have accepted the trade order execution with the OK button in the last step, you are once more presented with a summary of the transactions to be created.

title: Step 4 - Executed transactions
body: The actual trade order execution, or marking your trade orders as Executed and creating the listed transactions will be done in the background - you can close the summary of the transactions and continue using FA while the transactions are being created. Once the trade order execution is finished in the background, you are presented with a message on the bottom right-hand corner of the view: "Trade order execution doneCreated transactions: x".

title: Information set to executed trade orders in client portfolio
body: The status of trade orders that were involved in the execution is set to "Executed" - this indicates that the order was executed and a transaction was created based on it.

title: Information set to executed trade orders in client portfolio
body: When executing trade orders via Trade order execution, trade order's values are not changed. The trade order remains with the values it had before the execution, and the resulted transaction will be created with the information you define during execution. This allows you to easily see from the trade order "what you asked for" and from the transaction "what you got".

title: Information set to executed trade orders in client portfolio
body: You can easily access the transaction created based on a trade order through right-clicking a trade order on the Trade orders view and selecting to Open linked transaction - this opens up the Transaction window showing the details of the transaction created based on execution that specific trade order.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: For the transactions created via executing trade orders, certain information is set based on the information defined for the trade orders or their securities, information defined in the trade order execution or based on information of the portfolio the transaction is created to:

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The account of the transactions is set to be:

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The account set to the trade order. If an account is set to the trade order, this account is used for the transaction as well.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: If "No account" is set for the trade order, then when executing the trade order, AUTO logic is applied:

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The account in the portfolio with the same currency as the trade order is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: If an account with the same currency as the trade order cannot be found from the portfolio, then the portfolio's default account is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The marketplace and settlement place of the transactions is set to be:

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The marketplace/settlement place set for the trade order. If a marketplace/settlement place is set for the trade order, this marketplace/settlement place is used for the transaction as well.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The marketplace/settlement place set for the trade order's security. If you have defined a marketplace/settlement place for your security, the transaction created through trade order execution will inherit the security's marketplace/settlement place.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The reference of the transaction is set to be:

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The reference number defined on your trade order. All transactions created based on the trade order with Trade order execution are identified with the same reference number, allowing you to easily search for them.

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The tags of the transaction (applies only to the transaction in customer's portfolio) are set to be:

title: Information set to transactions in client portfolio
body: The tags you had selected on your trade order, if you have the tags available as transaction tags as well. If you want your transactions to inherit the tags you set for your trade orders, make sure the tags are defined in tags preferences both for trade orders and transactions.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: When executing your trade orders directly, you end up with one transaction per trade order in your client portfolio. However, when executing trade orders via a counter portfolio, you can end up with in addition maximum three additional transactions per trade order in your counter portfolio. The following transactions can be created by trade order execution:

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: A transaction for the trade order in your client's portfolio. This transaction is created every time a trade order is executed: the executed information is saved as a transaction in the client portfolio.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: A counter transaction for the trade order in the selected counter portfolio. If you have selected to "execute trade orders via a counter portfolio", a counter transaction is created to your selected counter portfolio based on the executed information if you have defined a transaction type for "Counter transaction" in the trade order execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: A cash transaction for the trade order in the selected counter portfolio. If you have selected to "execute trade orders via a counter portfolio", a cash transaction is created to your selected counter portfolio based on the executed information if you have defined a transaction type for "Cash transaction" in the trade order execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: A market transaction for the trade order(s) in the selected counter portfolio. If you have selected to "execute trade orders via a counter portfolio" and to "execute a transaction in the market", a market transaction is created to your selected counter portfolio based on the market transaction information you have defined in the trade order execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: When executing trade orders via a counter portfolio, the counters and counter portfolios are set to the trade orders based on the information defined in the trade order execution:

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: The counter of these transactions is set to be:

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the transaction in the client portfolio, the counter is set to be the primary contact of the "Counter portfolio" selected in the execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the counter transaction in the counter portfolio, the counter is set to be the counter defined for the trade order OR if not defined, the "Counter" defined in the market transaction step of the execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the cash transaction in the counter portfolio, the counter is set to be the "Counter" defined in the market transaction step of the execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the market transaction in the counter portfolio, the counter is set to be the "Counter" defined in the market transaction step of the execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: The counter portfolio of these transactions is set to be:

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the transaction in the client portfolio, the counter portfolio is set to be the "Counter portfolio" selected in the execution.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the counter transaction in the counter portfolio, the counter portfolio is set to be the counter portfolio defined for the trade order OR if not defined, the client portfolio the transaction / trade order.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the cash transaction in the counter portfolio, the counter portfolio is set to be the client portfolio the transaction / trade order.

title: Information set to transactions in counter portfolio
body: For the market transaction in the counter portfolio, no counter portfolio is set.

title: Confirm trade orders (Excel)
body: Confirm trade orders (Excel) on the Trade orders view you allows you to execute trade orders created in the system that have been confirmed in the market with an XLSX file.

title: Steps to execute trade orders with an Excel file
body: To execute trade orders by importing them as an XLSX file:

title: Steps to execute trade orders with an Excel file
body: Export your open trade orders from the Trade orders view. Search for the trade orders you want to send forward, and click the XLS icon at the top-right of the view to export your search result as an XLSX file. Make sure you have selected all necessary information as visible columns on the view so that they will be included in you export.

title: Steps to execute trade orders with an Excel file
body: Change the status of the trade orders you sent forward to be Executable. Changing the status of a trade order from open to executable locks the trade order and prevents making further changes to it before it is executed, guaranteeing you will have the same trade orders you sent forward untouched in the system.

title: Steps to execute trade orders with an Excel file
body: Once the orders are confirmed in the market, modify the XLSX file you originally exported from the system with the effective information (amount, date, unit price, exchange rate, and so on). Note that the date should be in the YYYY-MM-DD format.

title: Steps to execute trade orders with an Excel file
body: Import the same file back to the system through Confirm trade orders (Excel) to execute the trade orders.

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Before exporting your trade orders as an XLSX file, make sure you have at least the following required columns included:

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Order status

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Portfolio

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Security

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Transaction No

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Dates, amount, unit price (ef.), trade amount (ef.)

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Currency and FX rate

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: In addition to the required columns, you can have any number of columns you want to be able to send out to the market or define to your transactions when you execute your orders. For example, if you want to add costs during the execution, select the appropriate "cost" and "cost type" columns to be visible in your export file.

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: When importing the exported XLSX file back into the system with the Confirm trade orders (Excel), the XLSX file you are importing back to the system has to contain the same columns you currently have visible on the Trade orders view - if the columns and their order in the file you are importing back to the system don't match to the columns currently visible on the Trade orders view, the system doesn't recognize the trade orders you are executing.

title: Pre-requisites for executing trade orders with Excel
body: Confirm trade orders (Excel) works against different searches with different columns you have saved on the Trade orders view - just make sure you have the right saved search tab open when starting to confirm the trade orders and the columns in the opened tab match to the columns in your XLSX file.

title: Confirm trade orders (Excel) window
body: Confirm trade orders (Excel) on the Trade orders view you allows you to execute trade orders created in the system that have been confirmed in the market with an XLSX file.

title: Confirm trade orders (Excel) window
body: Once you have started the execution, the first step is to upload the XLSX file you want to use to execute the trade orders. Make sure you are on the correct tab - the XLSX file you upload should contain the same columns you currently have visible on the Trade orders view.

title: Confirm trade orders (Excel) window
body: Trade orders found in the uploaded XLSX file are listed in the second step. The Status column indicates whether a trade order in your file can be found as "open" or "executable" in the system, and can thus be executed. Saved / Ignored transactions at the top indicates the number of trade orders in your imported file that would be executed / ignored when you accept and save the execution.

title: Confirm trade orders (Excel) window
body: You can either click Back to upload to re-upload the file or click Save to execute the trade orders. This creates transactions based on the information in your file and in the system (the columns missing from the file are copied from trade orders). The status of your trade orders changes to Executed. Only the trade orders visible will be executed - if you want to execute all trade orders within your file, clear all search criteria before saving, and if you want to execute only some of the trade orders, utilize the search criteria to restrict the trade orders to be executed.

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: Transactions are created based on the information in the Excel file and in the system. You have modified the Excel file you originally exported from the system with the realized information (amount, date, unit price, exchange rate, etc.), and that information is used to create the transactions. If some information is present in the system but missing from the file (for example, internal info, tags, marketplace), it is also copied to the transactions.

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: Account of the transaction is set to be:

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: The account set to the trade order. If an account is set to the trade order, this account is used for the transaction as well.

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: If there is "No account" set for the trade order, then when executing the trade order, AUTO logic is applied:

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: The account in the portfolio with the same currency as the trade order is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: If an account with the same currency as the trade order cannot be found from the portfolio, then the portfolio's default account is set as the account of the trade order.

title: Transactions created for executed trade orders
body: If no accounts can be found from the portfolio, then the shared accounts available for the portfolio are used in the same order: by default setting the shared account with the same currency as the trade order, and if not found, then setting the shared default account.

title: Queries view
body: Queries view allows you to make customized searches against the FA database in SQL. Queries is an efficient way of searching and aggregating information that is not directly supported by the other search views. Queries can be used for example for mass searches and aggregating information.

title: Queries view
body: You can:

title: Queries view
body: Make ad-hoc searches. Click Show query to enter the query, and then click Search. If a query takes too long or if you need to edit the parameters, click Stop.

title: Queries view
body: Save your queries for later use. When you save your query for later use, you can give it a descriptive name and decide who to share it with.

title: Queries view
body: Export the results of any query as PDF or XLS.

title: Queries view
body: Use your saved queries as sections within your Dashboard - If your query returns at least one numeric value, instead of showing the data as a table, you can draw the results of your query as a chart on the Dashboard.

title: Queries view
body: Save your saved queries as a report template - If your query supports the $P(portfolioId) parameter, you can save your query as a report template and use it as any other report. The queries saved as report templates are identified with the file icon within the saved query tab.

title: Queries view
body: Show data to your logged-in users in FA Front.

title: Building a query
body: A query is an SQL query against the FA database. In most cases, the database is MySQL so the SQL needs to be compatible with that. Query needs to be any valid SELECT query against the database - no other types of queries are allowed.

title: Building a query
body:
SELECT s.name AS Name, s.isin_code as ISIN
FROM pm2_security s
SELECT * FROM pm2_security

title: Building a query
body: Since the data in FA is divided into multiple tables, we recommend using joins to combine the data.

title: Building a query
body: More information on building SQL queries: SQL tutorial, MySQL Functions, MySQL Select syntax, MySQL Subqueries.

title: Building a query
body: You can build your queries in the Queries view. Enable the query editor by clicking Show query, and type or copy-paste your query into the text area.The query editor is context-sensitive and supports building the query in the following way:

title: Building a query
body: [CTRL + Space]

title: Building a query
body: Lists all the available database tables.

title: Building a query
body: <table name>[.]

title: Building a query
body: Lists all the available table columns.

title: Building a query
body: <table alias>[.]

title: Building a query
body: List all the available table columns.

title: Building a query
body: [CTRL + Space] then [$]

title: Building a query
body: Lists all the available custom functions supported.

title: Building a query
body: [Enter]

title: Building a query
body: Inserts a line break.

title: Building a query
body: [CTRL + Enter]

title: Building a query
body: Executes the query.

title: Examples
body: Listing assets under managements of all the EUR based portfolios over time:

title: Examples
body:
SELECT r.report_date AS Date, ROUND(SUM(r.market_value),2) AS AUM, count(p.id) AS Portfolios
FROM pm2_pf_report r
LEFT JOIN pm2_portfolio p ON p.id = r.pf_id
LEFT JOIN pm2_security cur ON cur.id = p.currency
WHERE cur.security_code='EUR' AND ( month(r.report_date) != month(ADDDATE(r.report_date, INTERVAL 1 DAY)) OR ( r.report_date = CURDATE()) )
GROUP BY Date
ORDER BY r.report_date ASC

title: Examples
body: Listing top ten biggest portfolios on the selected date:

title: Examples
body:
SELECT p.name AS Portfolio, ROUND(r.market_value,2) AS AUM
FROM pm2_pf_report r
LEFT JOIN pm2_portfolio p ON p.id = r.pf_id
LEFT JOIN pm2_security cur ON cur.id = p.currency
WHERE cur.security_code='EUR' AND r.report_date = $P(endDate)
ORDER BY AUM DESC
LIMIT 10

title: Query parameters
body: By embedding certain parameters into your query, you can allow your users to select which contact, portfolio, security, user or dates they want to run the query with. When parameters are inserted into the query, the Queries view shows the corresponding field where the user can select the parameter value.

title: List of parameters
body: $P(portfolioId), $P(contactId), $P(securityId) and $P(userId)

title: List of parameters
body: Enables the group/customer/portfolio selector, contact selector, security selector or user selector. These can be used to narrow down the portfolios that the query is targeted to.

title: List of parameters
body: Portfolios based on selected group/customer/portfolio:

title: List of parameters
body:
SELECT p.id AS id
FROM pm2_portfolio p
WHERE p.id in $P(portfolioId)

title: List of parameters
body: $P(startDate) and/or $P(endDate)

title: List of parameters
body: Enables one or two date selectors. These can be used to narrow down the date or a date range.

title: List of parameters
body: Transactions between start date and end date:

title: List of parameters
body:
SELECT t.id AS id
FROM pm2_transaction t
WHERE t.transaction_date >= $P(startDate) AND t.transaction_date <= $P(endDate)

title: List of parameters
body: $P(customParameter)

title: List of parameters
body: Allows you to define your own parameters to narrow down the result. The custom parameters result in a text field in the Queries view, allowing you to type in the parameter value.

title: List of parameters
body: Best practices on using custom parameters:

title: List of parameters
body: Use custom parameters as you would use fixed parameters - you should include the custom parameter in your WHERE clause (for example WHERE name = "$P(name)"), allowing the user to type in a number or text that would be inserted into the query.

title: List of parameters
body: The parameter value the user enters into the field is inserted into the query as is. For example, if you are expecting the user to type in text, place the parameter in "", for example WHERE name = "$P(name)".

title: List of parameters
body: It is technically possible to for example write an entire SQL clause in the custom parameter field, however, this is NOT the best practice to use custom parameters.

title: List of parameters
body: "My customers" for logged in user:

title: List of parameters
body:
SELECT name, contact_idFROM pm2_contact c
WHERE c.id IN $V(currentUserContactIdsExtended) AND type = 1

title: Query variables
body: You can embed variables into your query to dynamically fetch the logged in user’s user name, linked contact, or a list of contacts or portfolios the logged in user can see with limited visibility or extended limited visibility. This allows you to easily build queries that aggregate data from contacts or portfolios the logged in user represents, for example for more extensive Dashboards.

title: List of variables
body: $V(currentUserId), $V(currentUserLinkedContactId), $V(currentUserContactIds) and $V(currentUserPortfolioIds)

title: List of variables
body: Allows you run the query against the information the system can dig out from the logged in user: who is the logged in user, which contact is the user linked to, and what contacts and portfolios the user can see based on representative / asset manager structures used for limited visibility and extended limited visibility.

title: List of variables
body: "My customers" for logged in user:

title: List of variables
body:
SELECT name, contact_id
FROM pm2_contact c
WHERE c.id IN $V(currentUserContactIdsExtended) AND type = 1

title: List of variables
body: Newest entries in user audit for logged in user:

title: List of variables
body:
SELECT * FROM AUDIT_USER
WHERE user_name = $V(currentUserId)
ORDER BY log_time DESC
LIMIT 10

title: List of variables
body: Open trade orders in portfolios the logged in user is allowed to see:

title: List of variables
body:
SELECT * FROM pm2_transaction
WHERE pf_id IN $V(currentUserContactIdsExtended)
AND status = 'ORDER'
AND order_status = 4

title: Query variables throughout the application
body: Regardless on where you use your query from, the variable values get passed to your query based on the logged in user's information. This is applied in Dashboard and Front (Datagrid + Custom content).

title: Query variables throughout the application
body: On the Queries view you can "test" the variables against different users in the system through through "Run as" - select the user you want to run the query as, and the result is shown according to the user you select. By default, the field is filled in with your user name, but you can change it to run the query as any other user in the application.

title: Data structure
body: The data in FA is structured into multiple database tables. Use SHOW TABLES to see all tables in the database, and DESCRIBE <table name> (for example, "DESCRIBE pm2_transaction") to view properties of the table.

title: General structure
body: The general structure is as follows:

title: Portfolio values and reporting
body: The structure of the report tables / entities is as follows:

title: Portfolio values and reporting
body: PortfolioReport (Portfolio)

title: Portfolio values and reporting
body: PortfolioReportItem (Position)

title: Portfolio values and reporting
body: PortfolioReportSubItem (Purchase lot)

title: Portfolio values and reporting
body: AccountItem (Account)

title: Portfolio values and reporting
body: AccountSubItem (Cashflow in the account)

title: pm2_pf_rep_sub_item (PortfolioReportSubItem)
body: Purhase lots in portfolio currency. Data gathered from transactions.

title: Obfuscating client data in the database
body: You have an option to obfuscate certain sensitive client information before storing it into the database. The purpose of this feature is to ensure that information that could identify individual clients from the data can only be accessed by authenticated and authorized users of the application - that is, neither administrators of the application’s technical environment nor anyone getting an access of a database backup would be able to access the sensitive information.

title: Obfuscating client data in the database
body: Sensitive client data is obfuscated using a simple substitution cipher. This approach was selected to maintain the usability of the system: users can still search and filter all data, even when it is obfuscated in the database.

title: Obfuscating client data in the database
body: Obfuscation is only applied to fields that might contain sensitive client information, including contact’s name, external ID and address, portfolio’s email, profile data, and user information, such as first name, last name and email address.

title: Obfuscating client data in the database
body: Obfuscation is limited to upper- and lower-case Latin characters, numbers, and most common Scandinavian characters - for example Cyrillic and Arabic characters are not obfuscated but stored in the database as they are.

title: Obfuscating client data in the database
body: Obfuscating certain client data in the database is available from FA 3.6 onward. Obfuscation is enabled on the application level and requires certain preparations before it can be taken into use. If you are interested in this feature, contact FA for more details.

title: Encrypted characters
body: Simple substitution cipher is used for obfuscating the data.

title: Encrypted characters
body: The set of characters to encrypt is limited to:

title: Encrypted characters
body: Upper- and lowercase Latin characters (a-z, A-Z).

title: Encrypted characters
body: Numbers (0-9).

title: Encrypted characters
body: Scandinavian characters ÅåÄäÖöÆæØø.

title: Encrypted characters
body: Any other characters besides these are not encrypted. For example, Cyrillic or Arabic characters will remain as is.

title: Fields
body: The following fields in the following entities / database tables are obfuscated:

title: Fields
body: Contact – Database table: pm2_contact

title: Fields
body: Address – Database table: pm2_address

title: Fields
body: Portfolio – Database table: pm2_portfolio

title: Fields
body: ProfileAttribute2 – Database table: pm2_profile2_attribute

title: Fields
body: User – Database table: pm2_user

title: Fields
body: Revision info – Database table: revision_info

title: Fields
body: Other fields. In addition to the fields above, the following VO table fields also indirectly end up as encrypted when the VO table is populated / updated:

title: Fields
body: Database table: pm2_transaction_vo

title: Fields
body: Database table: pm2_customer_portfolio_search

title: Logs
body: Logs

title: Track data modifications through versions
body: You can follow the changes made to contact, portfolio, transaction, trade order, security and market price data, postings, posting rules or transaction type settings. Every time someone saves changes to one of these entities, a new version is saved in the system. You can view these versions and see who changed what data and when.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: To view the versions for each contact, portfolio, transaction, trade order, security, market price information, posting rule or transaction type setting, click Versions button in the corresponding window. To view posting versions, right-click the posting in the Bookkeeping view and choose Versions. The Versions window that opens shows the newest 50 versions with the time of the version, the user who made the changes and the type of the change.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The versions are listed in the upper part of the window, and are divided into columns:

title: Viewing individual versions
body: Revision date

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The date and time of the version. Latest version is indicated with (Latest).

title: Viewing individual versions
body: User name

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The user name of the user who has made the change.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: Revision type

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The type of the change.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: Action

title: Viewing individual versions
body: The action that caused the version, more detailed description of how the change was initiated.

title: Viewing individual versions
body: You can view more details of the version by clicking a version from the list - the information saved with the version is shown in the lower part of the window.

title: Comparing versions
body: You can also compare versions with each other, by comparing a version to the latest version or choosing multiple versions from the list with the Ctrl button and comparing these against each other. The differences are highlighted when comparing revisions. You can compare revision with a right-click of you mouse, where you can find the following options:

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare with latest

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen version to the latest version.

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare with latest (only difference)

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen version to the latest version, showing only differences.

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare each other

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen versions with each other.

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare each other (only difference)

title: Comparing versions
body: Compare the chosen versions with each other, showing only differences.

title: Administration view
body: Administration view gathers together advanced administrative features, allowing you for example to manage processes, documents, application logs, etc.

title: Processes
body: Processes section allows you to manage processes easily and effectively. You can for example view and manage all available process configurations, processes and deployments. In addition, you can configure your processes through the Administration view.

title: Processes
body: Changes to process configurations are audited - user audit tracks changes users make to process configurations through Administration view. Every time a user makes a change to configurations of an installed process, user audit contains a message ”User [username] added/modified/deleted configurations of process [id]”. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Documents
body: Documents section allows you to manage all documents stored in the system. To learn more, see Administer documents in FA Admin guide.

title: Run script
body: Run script section allows FA's admin users to run scripts in the application. This feature is available to FA's admin users only.

title: Delete data
body: Delete data section provides you with functionality to delete all data from the system.

title: Delete data
body: From FA 3.6 onward, this feature is no longer available in production environments - these features are useful in data migration phase during deployment, but are disabled in production environments to ensure all data is not accidentally deleted. This feature can be enabled for the deployment phase through environment variables when installing FA.

title: Delete data
body: Available delete data options:

title: Delete data
body: Delete all portfolio reports - deletes all portfolio reports from the system

title: Delete data
body: Delete all transactions - deletes all transactions from the system

title: Delete data
body: Delete all portfolios - deletes all portfolios from the system

title: Delete data
body: Delete all contacts - deletes all contacts from the system

title: Delete data
body: Delete all securities - deletes all securities from the system

title: Delete data
body: You should always delete data in the order the delete functions are listed in the Delete data tab. If you want to remove all data from the system, first delete the portfolio reports, then the transactions, portfolios, contacts and securities. The deleting of data is always started with the deleting of the portfolio reports, and after this the list of Delete functions are gone through as far as needed.

title: Delete data
body: NOTE! The functions will delete all data from the system, and the information to be deleted can't be chosen, filtered or restored. Deleting of all data is confirmed with a popup.

title: Logging
body: Logging section allows you to access application logs.

title: API
body: In the API section, you can view the documentation of APIs and manage API tokens. Changes to API tokens are audited - user audit (system audit before FA 3.9) tracks changes users make to API tokens in the Administration view. Every time a user makes a change in an API token, the system audit contains a message “User [username] created / deleted API token [token name]” (Available from FA 3.6 onward).

title: Preference view
body: Preference view gathers together all application preferences, providing you with an easy way to browse through and manage all your preferences in one place.

title: Preference view
body: You can access your preferences by navigating through the tree on the left. Preferences are grouped under common titles and ordered alphabetically to help you to find them – you can easily open and close the sections with a single click.

title: Preference view
body: You are notified if your changes to the preferences have been successfully saved or if you are unable to delete a preference that is already in use.

title: Preference - Administration
body: The Administration section in Preference is used only by FA administrators. Clients can’t access these settings.

title: Banner
body: In Banner preferences, you can define HTML to be displayed into the red toolbar. This allows you to utilize the space in the red toolbar more extensively, and to for example easily distinguish your test and production environments with a descriptive text.

title: Banner
body:
For example, HTML

TEST ENVIRONMENT

allows you to enter a noticeable text centered in the red banner.

title: Document management
body: Document management preferences allow you to adjust how your users can upload documents into the system (available from FA 3.5 onward).

title: Document management
body: Define maximum size for all uploaded files in megabytes (MB)

title: Document management
body: Allows you to define a maximum file size for documents your user can upload to the system. By default, there is no maximum file size.

title: Document management
body: Limit the frequency of document uploads

title: Document management
body: Allows you to define how many documents a user can upload, and how frequently rights to upload new documents will be available (e.g. a user can receive 1 new document to upload every 10 seconds). You can control the upload frequency with three settings:

title: Document management
body: Number of documents user can upload – The number of documents user can upload without any limit on upload frequency. By default, the number of documents is set to 1000.

title: Document management
body: Number of new documents to upload user receives at once – The number of new documents upload "rights" the user receives at the defined interval. By default, the number of new documents is set to 1000.

title: Document management
body: How often (seconds) user receives the new documents to upload – The freguency: how often the user gets the new document upload "rights". By default, the number of time is set to 1 second.

title: Document management
body: With the default configurations, users can upload 1000 documents without any limit, and get 1000 new documents to upload every second - in practice, this means that there is by default no limit on document upload frequency, unless the user tries to upload more than 1000 documents a second.

title: Document management
body: Adjusting the preferences above allows you to limit file uploads. If a user tries to upload files more frequently than allowed, the upload is prevented with a notification.

title: Document management
body: For example, set the number of documents to 5, new documents to 1, and time to 10 seconds. With this configuration, your users are able to upload 5 documents without a limit and will receive 1 new document to upload every 10 seconds. Every time your user uploads a document, the number of "uploads left" is reduced from five - after one upload, you have four uploads left, etc. The number of documents gets restored with one new document every ten seconds - if the user uploaded one document, reducing the "number of uploads left" to four, after ten seconds, the user would again have rights for full five uploads. If the user uploads more than five documents simultaneously or right after each other within ten seconds, further uploads are prevented until the user gets a "refill" of new documents to upload.

title: Email settings
body: Email settings contain fields for defining the settings for sending the emails (defined by FA when email reporting is enabled).

title: General
body: You can set the following general preferences:

title: General
body: Document management

title: General
body: Enable or disable document management. If enabled, documents can be attached to contacts, portfolios, transactions, and securities in the corresponding windows.

title: General
body: Language

title: General
body: Set the default language of the application to be either Suomi, English, or Svenska. The language setting defines the default language of the application: the user interface is shown with the selected language by default. The user can change the language of the user interface from Action - Languages (the language selection specific to the user name).

title: General
body: Enter button functionality

title: General
body: Define how the Enter key behaves in FA Portfolio windows. The following options are available:

title: General
body: Enter navigates to the next field: Set the Enter key to behave as the tabulator, navigating to the next field when pressed. Selected by default.

title: General
body: Enter submits the form: Set the Enter key to submit the open form when pressed (Enter acts as the Save / OK buttons).

title: General
body: Enter does not do anything: The Enter key has no extra functions.

title: General
body: Default search

title: General
body: Select the default search criteria to show when you open a view. You can choose from the following options:

title: General
body: Extended search: The views show all search criteria. You can use the quick search by clicking Show quick search. Selected by default.

title: General
body: Quick search: The views show the quick search. You can use the extended search by clicking Show extended search.

title: Market data connection
body: The market data connection preferences are visible only if the functionality to import market data from an external source is enabled. Define the market data information to the field:

title: Market data connection
body: Earliest date of observation

title: Market data connection
body: Set the earliest date of the market data observations imported. External market price sources often have a long history of market price observations available, and it might not be worthwhile to save the entire market data history to FA. This field allows you to define the earliest date of market data observations.

title: Market data connection
body: Number of days market prices are fetched for in the nightly run

title: Market data connection
body: Define how many day's market data observations are fetched for and saved as market prices during the nightly run. The nightly run automatically fetches market prices for "Active" securities, for which a corresponding update code is defined. The default number of days to fetch during the nightly run is 5: this means that every night, including weekends, the prices from the previous 5 days are fetched and saved for securities as market prices. For example, setting the number of days as 1 means that on Saturday, the close price from Friday is fetched. Similarly, on Monday, the close price from Sunday is fetched. Note that it is unlikely there is a price available for Sunday.

title: Performance calculation
body: Performance calculation preferences define how TWR is calculated and stored.

title: Performance calculation
body: Timing of intra-day cashflows in TWR calculation

title: Performance calculation
body: An option to define how net cash flows or net exposure affect the base for the daily TWR formula.

title: Performance calculation
body: Use imported TWR up to

title: Performance calculation
body: The date until which Analytics+ should use pre-calculated TWR values (instead of calculating values on the fly). Importing pre-calculated TWR values helps you speed up the usage of Analytics+. For more details, see File format for importing TWR.

title: Permissions
body: Permission preferences allow you to define and adjust permissions of each user role, i.e. adjust the rights to use the system per user role. The permissions are used to what users can access, view and edit when using FA.

title: Permissions
body: To switch between the tabs, click on them or use the icon at the bottom of the view.

title: Restrict reports to roles
body: Restricting reports to roles allows you to define which user roles have access to certain reports. Enter one or several semicolon-separated roles next to the report and click Save. If you leave the field empty, all users can generate the report in the Report window.

title: Restrict reports to roles
body: If a report is included in the report package, the user can generate only those reports in the package they have access to. The user gets a warning that some reports included in the package are unavailable. To learn more about the report packages, see the Report packages section.

title: Session timeout
body: Session timeout preferences allow you to control the application life cycle through "session timeout" and "heartbeat interval". These parameters are applied when a user is inactive, but the application is open and stays idle. (Available from FA 3.5 onward)

title: Session timeout
body: Heartbeat interval (minutes)

title: Session timeout
body: The default is 5 minutes. Heartbeat interval controls how often heartbeats that keep the user's session alive are sent. "UI instances are cleaned up if no communication is received from them after some time. If no other server requests are made, the client side sends keep-alive heartbeat requests. A UI is kept alive for as long as requests, or heartbeats, are received from it.”

title: Session timeout
body: Session timeout (minutes)

title: Session timeout
body: Default 30 minutes. Session timeout defines the time period for which the application remains “alive” without user interaction. Timeout is reset if the user performs some action within the application.

title: Session timeout
body: Manipulating session length by adjusting these two parameters in FA Back and the corresponding KeyCloak setting means that the application can function in two ways:

title: Session timeout
body: If the heartbeat is set to be longer than the session timeout, the session will always die after the timeout.

title: Session timeout
body: If the heartbeat interval is shorter than the session, the session will never expire.

title: Update report
body: Update report preferences allow you to define how and when portfolio report data is updated.

title: Update report
body: Disable report updates

title: Update report
body: Disables all report updates and blocks all purchase lot and position calculations from being triggered. Use this option to speed up data import when importing large volumes of data. This also overrides "Update reports immediately” if both are selected. After the import is completed, you should:

title: Update report
body: Re-enable report updates in Preferences.

title: Update report
body: Recalculate the report data. Click Update in the top menu and choose Recalculate all report data of all portfolios.

title: Update report
body: Re-run posting rules if they are used. Click the Generate postings at the bottom of the Transactions view.

title: Update report
body: Update reports immediately

title: Update report
body: Enables portfolio positions to update immediately after changes in the data. When disabled, the positions have to be updated manually or via an automatic position calculation at night. Purchase lots are calculated immediately in either case. Enabling this is recommended.

title: Update report
body: Automatically update reports

title: Update report
body: Enables or disables automatic nightly report data update. If you are using a market data connector, the nightly report data update first fetches the latest market price entries through your market data connector and then recalculates report data with the latest close prices.

title: Update report
body: Update time

title: Update report
body: Define the time for the daily report update in the form hh:mm (for example 01:00). Daily report update is recommended to run at night so that report data is ready in the morning. If you are using a market data connector to fetch prices, adjust the time so that yesterday's prices are available through the connector when the nightly report data update begins.

title: Update report
body: Number of days to store report calculation records

title: Update report
body: Define the number of days for storing information about completed report calculations.

title: Update report
body: Nightly report data updates are audited - system audit tracks when the system automatically fetches market prices through a market data connector and updates report data at night. Every time the system starts to fetch prices, the system audit contains a message “Nightly close price updates and report calculations started” and once prices have been fetched, the system audit contains a message “Nightly close price updates done, report calculations scheduled”. (Available from FA 3.10 onward)

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Bookkeeping preferences include settings for managing and setting up accounting. The first steps in setting up accounting are to 1) create bookkeeping accounts in the system through the Account set preferences and 2) create appropriate posting rules in the Posting rule preferences.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in bookkeeping preferences are tracked:

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in account sets and posting rules are recorded in FA audit logs available in the FA Admin Console: FA audit logs.

title: Preference - Bookkeeping
body: Changes in posting rules are recorded in versions of each posting rule: Track data modifications through versions.

title: Account set
body: In the Account set you can define account sets to use in posting rules. An account set can consist of several individual accounts. Define an account number and name for each account. You can specify the account number by typing it in or you can set it dynamically – the system will use the account number from the security or portfolio of the transaction.
